charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Myself and 3 members of my section will be attending the 2021 100 KM trailwalker event, we will carry 15KG throughout and have 30 hours to complete this, however we aim to do it much quicker. This is in support of Oxfam GB and the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

Being a part of the King's Royal Hussars an opportunity to raise money for Gurkha veterans was one we could not pass up. The KRH and RGR served alongside each other at the battle of medicina in Italy. Since then the KRH have worn the Gurkha crossed Kukri badge as a symbol of the allegiance between the regiments. 

The Gurkhas have served alongside Britain for over 200 years, and have subsequently been involved in every major conflict that Britain has been in since then. This is an opportunity for us to give back to those who gave so much for us.

The target for us is £1400 but if we exceed this figure then that would be amazing. If you can donate anything to help this cause then it would be greatly appreciated. Please could you share this around your friends to help us achieve our target.


Many thanks 

Scott

Adam

Dan 

Laura

story:
The Trailwalker Relay is a challenge for teams to walk 100km collectively, splitting up the distance between their team members and completing it in the space of a week. This event supports the work of both Oxfam GB and The Gurkha Welfare Trust.

I love a stroll and so I've made the completely sane decision to take this on solo! My start date is 27th Sept and between then and 4th Oct, I'll walk 100km to support the work of Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

I'm hoping to get these kilometres completed in Shropshire and my working area of Merseyside and Lancashire and will track it all on Strava.... Horrendous weather and all!

Thank you for all and any support. :) xx

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Dear friends and families,

Trailwalker Relay is a virtual walking/running challenge developed in response to the Covid-19 pandemic whilst the traditional Trailwalker event is unable to go ahead. QG SIGNALS has always been an integral part of organizing the Trailwalker event for years.

My team, BST Runners Blue, from Brunei Signal Troop is taking part in the Trail-walker Relay, completing 100 km on the 22nd of September this year to mark the 71st Regimental Birthday of the Queen’s Gurkha Signals (QGS). 

Both, the Gurkha Welfare trust & the Oxfam have been long-serving the Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal by looking after their welfare, offering medical care and financial aid, as well as bringing clean water to peoples’ doorstep.

We as the serving members of the QGS would like to continually support in appreciation of the great work by both the organisations. Please join my team and me in helping to raise fund to support the work of both the Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

With sincere gratitude,

Team BST Runners Blue

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Its been a while since us, as a group got together to challenge ourselves and raise money for a worthwhile cause along the way! Previously we have completed a Sky Dive as well as a 48 hour non stop bike-a-thon! 

So what next...well what better than to step away from the bikes and in to the great outdoors, but not just any outdoors, the great British outdoors in the stunning South Downs! 

As a team we will be trekking 100km in under 30 hours testing our minds and bodies (and friendships) to the limit! All this is aid of Oxfam and help end poverty with every step!

We would love your support and will keep you updated leading up to the adventure and even throughout as we struggle through the 100km together.

All and any donation is massively appreciated and welcomed, please dig deep as this is isn't going to be easy and your donations will drive us to succeed!

Big thanks in advance, 

The Trekfast Club

Dan, Amit, Niki & Haroon

story:
Just 4 of us going for a stroll.........

Trailwalker is the ultimate team endurance event. The challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km non-stop across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours as a team of four, with our support crew to help us get to the finish line. As we train, trek and fundraise for Trailwalker 2020, we will be helping to end poverty around the world. The money raised will support both the work of Oxfam as well as the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

Thank you for your support.

Chris Line, Ben King, Paul Kavanagh and Spencer Sutcliff

story:
SOUTH DOWNS STOMPERS- YEAR OF LEGENDS

We are back for more! This year will be our third time taking part in the event, therefore, we'll officially and proudly be known as Trailwalker Legends! 

Thanks to all you generous people, to date we've raised over £5000! The GWT is a great charity and we hope you continue to support it. 

We kindly ask that you donate anything you can to help us meet our target of £1500; in previous years we've smashed the target, so again this year we hope to do well with so many generous supporters. 

Thank you very much for your continued support!

The Legendary...SOUTH DOWNS STOMPERS !!!

Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Due to the COVID pandemic, the annual Oxfam 100km footrace across the South Downs way has been cancelled. In light of this, members of Headquarters Army Recruiting and Initial Training Command (ARITC) and Recruiting Group (Capita) will be completing a 100km relay run and ascend the height of Everest on a stair climber in teams of 5 on 2nd Oct 2020. This will see individuals cover 20km of running and nearly 1700m of climbing in a single day. This will be done for two great causes; Oxfam GB and The Gurkha Welfare Trust; both key facilitators in the annual Trailwalker challenge, and both are charities that are close to our hearts. 

We would love it if you were able to donate something to support our efforts. 100% of the donations will go straight to Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

Many thanks

Jackie

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I've joined up with the 'Around the World in 79 Days' team to contribute my miles covered to their team target of travelling (virtually) around the world whilst connecting with countries who are worse affected than the UK by the coronavirus.

By helping ourselves, we will be helping others.  (In aid of UNICEF UK)

One day at a time,
One step at a time,
One vaccine at a time.

To do our part, 79Days has aligned with Unicef’s International Covid-response to prioritise the protection of health workers and the most vulnerable people across the globe. By supporting Unicef in this way, we will contribute to their goal of delivering 2 billion Covid-19 vaccines, 500 million tests and treatment – thus helping to open the door to a brighter future.

From buying and transporting supplies through to administering the vaccine, our efforts will help to deliver history. Our fundraising will help to ensure that:

- vaccines get to even the most remote places in the world.
- vaccines are safely stored using cold chain equipment.
- health workers are protected and trained to vaccinate their communities.

£31 = could provide a full kit to protect a health worker, including boots, gloves, masks and coveralls.

£45 = could provide cold chain equipment to safely store 500 doses of vaccines.

£63 = could transport 4205 doses of vaccines
title: Around the World in 79 days (In aid of UNICEF UK)
pageSummary: I will by cycling 20km per day for 79 days because I wish to help health workers & vulnerable people!

pageSummaryWhy: I wish to help health workers & vulnerable people!

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I am fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.
Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker on the frontline, including gloves, masks and coveralls, while just £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers.
The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.
Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.
title: My page to help a generation of children affected by Coronavirus
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: My page to help a generation of children affected by Coronavirus

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. charity.name: Unicef UK
owner: Sears NSPCC First team,  UNICEF Second team
story: Although Liz did not have any children of her own, her tireless interest and love of young people was manifested through her career choices. Her abundance of Godchildren amongst close friends and family is testament to her joy of being central to children's lives. Liz championed many children's charities during her lifetime, both in the UK and internationally. She sought to improve and transform the lives of disadvantaged children, through charities that focussed on introducing children to both the Arts and classical music, and supporting those that gave children access to inspirational activities. Liz highlighted the needs of children and teenagers who through life circumstances become carers, and tried to make their lives easier. She chose the NSPCC and UNICEF, for any donations made in her memory, possibly for a current disaster fund. As both charities are currently working very hard to support children specifically affected by the Coronavirus pandemic, we know that Liz would want to help them in achieving that aim.
title: UNICEF donation in memory of Dr Elizabeth Sears
pageSummary: Recognising Liz's life-long affinity with children because of her chosen career focus with young  people

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I am proud to be a member of UNICEF UK’s 2020 London Marathon Team.  I will be one person on a team of 33, covering 26.2 miles through the streets of London with 40,000 other runners in April.  I run to support UNICEF and their mission to protect & promote the rights of every child.

I have run for many teams over the years - Torrey Pines, NYU, PR Performance - but this will be the first time I've run for a charity.  I am truly honored to put on another singlet, represent UNICEF, and run to support every child in need.  UNICEF will help the children; I will run the 26.2 miles, and you all can help us both with your donations. 

My goal is to raise just over £2,000 (that is approx. $2,600 for my American friends).  This is what funds like that will allow UNICEF to do for children…

20 cents protects one child from polio

$6 buys a blanket to keep a baby warm in a hospital, day-care centre or refugee camp

$13 purchases exercise books, pens, pencils, textbooks and other school things to support the education of a child for a whole year

$25 provides mosquito nets to protect 7 families from deadly malaria

$178 provides school equipment for 40 children to continue with their education during an emergency or natural disaster

$336 allows the installation of a water pump to provide clean, safe water to a school or a whole village or community

$1,392 is the cost a temporary school or health centre for children who have survived a natural disaster, war or displacement to have a safe space to learn and play or receive medical care.

I appreciate any contributions you make.  This will be an incredible race and I'm stoked to run in my old neighborhood (studied abroad in London back in the day!)  Above all, I can't wait to run for UNICEF and their cause.  

Max
title: Max Avila - Team UNICEF UK

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Lockdown made us think we could run, so I'm running the 2020 Royal Parks Half Marathon, along with Levente Koroes, to fundraise for Unicef UK! They help and support children around the world, and your donation will help to provide children life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection. Help me smash their fundraising targets and help children worldwide. Any amount of donation or support is appreciated!

Take care!

-Kamilla

A kijárási korlátozás elhitette velem, hogy tudok futni, így Koroes Leventével részt veszünk az októberi Royal Parks Fél Maratonon Londonban, ahol a Unicef UK szervezetnek fogunk pénzt gyűjteni! Segíts, hogy futhassunk és gyermekek mindenhol a világon hozzájuthassanak a számukra szükséges ételhez, oktatáshoz és egészségügyi ellátáshoz! Bármilyen adományt és támogatást nagyra értékelünk! :)

Vigyázzatok magatokra!

-Kamilla

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
THANK YOU FOR YOUR DONATION-every penny is so appreciated and getting me that much closer to my goal- thank you! 

As many of you know I am GP by trade. I also have a keen interest in holistic medicine and  practice as a massage therapist ( Swedish and sports - 5-* Nirvana Spa trained), a reflexologist and a yoga teacher ( with the Yoga Alliance).

I have pledged to donate all proceeds from holistic practice towards this cause- so if you would like me to run a class for you  or would like to gift yourself or your friend/ family a treatment please don’t hesitate to get in touch ! A great way to look after yourself and give at the same time :) 

Lots of love 


Thanks for your support with my London Marathon JustGiving challenge!
My page donations will be sent direct to the charity in a fast and secure way. Its efficient, saves time and cuts costs for the charity. Let's do this!

story:
I started running back in 2016 and have been doing so on and off since. I have run 5K and 10K races before - I have never attempted a half-marathon, though, so when my teammate, Kamilla, sent me a link to the race, I got very excited - not only because I would have the opportunity in one of the most beautiful cities in the world, but also because I could raise money for an organisation that I believed in.

UNICEF helps children around the world, providing them with vaccines, nutrition and access to education. I would really appreciate it if you would consider donating.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The consumer legal teams of BT, EE and Plusnet are working together to walk 10 million steps in February, the equivalent of Bristol to the top of Mount Everest, to raise awareness of the significant barriers millions of young people face when trying to access education.

The world is currently home to the largest generation of young people ever. 1.8 billion young people are on the verge of entering the workforce and 85% of the jobs that today's learners will be doing in 2030 have not been invented yet.

But, collectively, women and girls walk more than 200 million hours daily just to collect water. This is time that could be spent in the classroom learning the skills they need for the future.

Please show your support by donating whatever you can to our challenge.

We walk so disadvantaged young people don’t have to.

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: NextGen supports the Unicef's Indonesia Earthquake and Tsunami Emergency Appeal
story:
Last Friday a catastrophic earthquake and tsunami hit Central Sulawesi. The devastation in Indonesia is immense, with reports of more than 1,200 casualties. This figure is set to rise as the missing are accounted for and the situation develops.

Unicef are on the frontlines of the relief effort, working alongside the Indonesian government and agencies to provide technical assistance and mobilise supplies. More than 48,000 people have been displaced, and over 1.5 million people affected by the disaster.

Unicef is particularly concerned for the safety and wellbeing of children who have lost their homes, become separated from their families and are sleeping rough. Children in Indonesia are already vulnerable as only 33 per cent of children under five are registered citizens.

The immediate needs of children include: evacuating the injured as well as providing medical services, food and emergency shelter.
title: NextGen supports Unicef's Indonesia Earthquake and Tsunami Emergency Appeal

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Help Save A Life! 

I have been very fortunate to be selected to run London Marathon 2020 for one of my favourite charity Unicef! The London marathon is a 26 mile run, one of the only problems that I will face is the fact that I cant really run! so here I am challenging myself, putting myself into a situation to help some of the most needy children across and around the world. I will hugely appreciate if you can kindly make a small donation to help me reach my target. I will be regularly posting updates on my training leading up to the 26 mile run. so stay tuned ladies and gentlemen. 

Catch me at the finish line!

We live in a dangerous world. Every day children face violence, disease and hunger. They are battered by the chaos of war, disaster and forced to flee their homes. Unicef ensures more of the worlds children are vaccinated, protected and educated. 

Lets all together help more children grow up to be healthier & happier. Unicef 80% of the worlds life saving food, making sure that children grow up healthy, happy and strong.

For 70 years Unicef have been there for children in danger. Unicef was created in 1946 to help protect children after World War 2 and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child is the basis of all of our work. Today we’re still helping children in some of the world’s most dangerous places.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I am a big believer that each one of us is like a small drop of water, and multiple drops make a puddle, and then a pond, a lake and then a sea.

Day by day, things seem to be getting worse, from poverty to lack of essential life conditions, malnutrition and vulnerability to disease. However, things are actually getting better, given steady development and the help of charitable organizations that focus their efforts on those that most need them.

I'm running the 2021 Royal Parks Half Marathon, given my recently discovered passion for long-distance exercise, as well as trying to give back and assist UNICEF UK to help the ones in need.

This money goes to assisting children, by:
  • treating them for malnutrition.
  • providing housing security, educational materials and school books.
  • vaccines for deadly, common diseases that most of us haven't heard much about, given that they don't exist anymore in developed countries.
  • sanitation facilities, access to soap and water, as well as clean living conditions.
Some key achievements of UNICEF's latest work:
  • Treated 4 million children for malnutrition, in 2017 alone, by giving them life-saving food, a high-energy peanut paste that is easy and cheap to make, yet very effective (brings a malnourished child back to health in about 5 weeks).
  • In 2015 alone, developed 22.3 million mosquito nets, to protect against dangerous mosquito bites which cause malaria. Last year, donations made 20 million measles vaccines possible.
  • 2019 - Provided school books and educational materials to 12.4 million children in need.
https://www.unicef.org.uk/what-we-do/

Please help me smash my fundraising target, every bit counts, and I will make sure to run the whole 21K!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
We provide bilingual ed programs with live music for children. We were working in schools and nurseries but had to stop all our lessons due to Covid-19. However, our students have always been our priority which led to the launch of our online classes last month to support parents during these tough times. 


The response has been amazing and we feel very grateful to be able to continue bringing value to our community from home when millions of people are unable to work. 


Soon we will be launching our first children’s book filled with stories and great songs to learn Spanish. We are so excited about it! 


To celebrate the release of our new music, we’ve decided to do a charity concert via Facebook Live. We hope this event will gather people from all around the world together. We just want to have a great time and make everyone smile during these tough times. All the funds will support UNICEF’s efforts to protect and save children’s lives during the Coronavirus crisis.


The Facebook live will be on May 9th at these times:

  • 4pm BST

  • 11am EDT

  • 5pm CEST

  • 10 am CDT 

  • 9am MDT


All you need to do is go to our Facebook page via this link at the time indicated. 

https://www.facebook.com/heyspanish/live


The money will help children and families all around the world that have been affected by Covid-19. The virus is not only affecting our health and economy but also keeping our children out of school. Not every child is lucky enough to be learning from home. Vulnerable groups are always the most hit by any crisis but it’s time for us to do something about it and protect others that don’t have the same support as we do.


Please donate to help us battle the COVID-19 crisis.

We would be really grateful for any donation however big or small.



With love, 


The HeySpanish team





For more information on what UNICEF is doing to protect our children, please visit their website: https://www.unicef.org

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: Journeys Through Coronavirus Land: Lessons from a pandemic
story:
Manfred is making his latest book available free to download via KDVI. In exchange, we're encouraging donations to the Save Generation Covid campaign to help Unicef expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.

Our journey together through the pandemic can lead us down a path of division or a more hopeful path of mutual responsibility, reconciliation and true renewal, ensuring healthier organisations and a better society for our children and future generations.

In his latest book Journeys into Coronavirus Land, Manfred Kets de Vries takes us through his ruminations during confinement, widening his explorations into group phenomenon, leadership and organisational dynamics and economic and environmental crisis. The central question is, how have each of us responded to this adversity and where will this journey lead us, individually and collectively?

The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. 

Donations will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

Get the book: https://www.kdvi.com/research_items/859

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
As part of the 79DaysUK fundraising team, I will be helping all participants to 'travel' around the world in 79 days (virtually) by delivering free online fitness classes four times per week. A fit body contributes to a fit mind and taking part with an event like this will help people to get up and move.

This all means that during Around the world in 79 days I will be delivering 60 online fitness classes to help people to get active and more connected.

Fund raised will go to Unicef UK to help with their efforts to bring both vaccine and PPE to health care workers and vulnerable people throughout the world - hence our theme of 'around the world'.

Your donation is greatly appreciated. Thank you.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The world is currently home to the largest generation of young people ever. 1.8 billion young people are on the verge of entering the workforce and 85% of the jobs that today's learners will be doing in 2030 have not been invented yet.

Collectively women and girls walk more than 200 million hours daily to collect water. This is time that could be spent in the classroom learning the digital skills they need for the future.BT and Unicef are working in partnership to equip young people with the digital skills they need for the lives of tomorrow.

By walking 5 miles a day for 1 week I am raising awareness of the significant barriers millions of young people face when trying to access education and demonstrating how BT and Unicef are working together to provide these young people with the digital skills they need for a successful future.

Please show your support by donating whatever you can spare to our challenge.

Thank you.

story:
This New Years Eve, Im going intergalactic as part of the worlds biggest, FREE online rave-a-thon to raise money for a charity close to my heart.

Along with thousands of fellow space comrades, and a line-up of global star DJs, were aiming to dance and stomp over 500 million steps - the distance from Earth to the moon!

There are also PRIZES up for grabs for the highest step count, most funds raised and wildest dance moves, all tracked in real time on the Raveship Leaderboard

Please DONATE or JOIN this free, inclusive and family-friendly party from home hosted by award-winning beatboxer, SK Shlomo, and help us RAVE TO THE MOON!

To see the full artist line-up or for more info visit:  https://ravetothemoon.tv

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
We at Wireless Federation, aim at fundraising for children in danger and supporting this particular cause, in collaboration with UNICEF. 

The outbreak of coronavirus brought suffering and misery for everybody across the globe and but has mostly affected those who are most vulnerable. Unicef is looking forward to generating funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by the pandemic especially in countries with weaker health systems.

Your small donation could provide enough for somebody who is in acute need of basic necessities like clothing, nutrition and safety from the disease. Together, we can not only help these vulnerable children but also the ones who've worked really hard to save our lives by risking theirs; health workers. 

Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members. Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to our page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

Stay home, stay safe and let's work for the betterment of the society, together.

Warm Regards,

Himanshu Johar

story: I want to push myself and help those in need. The 2020 Royal Parks Half Marathon is a great way to do that. I was shocked to learn that diarrhea kills 2,195 children every day—more than AIDS, malaria, and measles combined. Unicef helps bring that number (and other similar ones) down by helping these children get clean water and food. I decided to risk crapping my pants in my first Half Marathon ever in the hopes that others won't have to go through that daily. Unicef needs your help to support children around the world. Your donation will help to provide children life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection. Help me smash their fundraising targets and help children worldwide. Your donation will make a difference. Please donate whatever you can to my fundraiser for Unicef UK. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. Thank you

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
We are fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.

£30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker on the frontline, including gloves, masks and coveralls, while just £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers.

The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.

Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
While our world stopped turning almost one year ago, with us refocusing on our own problems and our relatives, war and misery remained the first reality of millions of humans on earth. 

COVID-19 and lockdown-announces in the news unfortunately conceal(ed) the increasing violence, rapes and attacks on civilians in Ethiopia, Yemen, Soudan, Syria... prompting young people and their families to flee crisis-ridden areas. In their journey to better beginnings in which they are exposed to detention, human trafficking and sexual exploitation, they are also often prisoners of borders that remain closed in an effort to contain COVID-19. They are left at even greater risk of harm, caught between the homes they have fled and an uncertain future.

In addition, since it disrupted food supply chains, the pandemic also accelerated the risks of famine, overwhelming nations already weakened by years of conflict.

What

I'm running the 2020 Royal Parks Half Marathon. I will be fundraising for Unicef, which I chose for its wide extent of action, and the many battles it leads worldwide for gender equality, a fair life for everyone, and most of all children rights. 

Help me smash their fundraising targets (min. £400/ €450 - Max.: reach for the stars ;)). Your donation will make a difference. To give you an idea, £400/€450 in sponsorship could provide a month’s supply of life-saving peanut paste to bring 17 malnourished children back to health...!

N.B.: The minimal target reach is 80%, must this target not be reached or the be event cancelled, the money will still be donated to UNICEF.

Contributions

  • < €10: a huge thank you !
  • €10 - €24: your name on my t-shirt 
  • €25 - €34: your name on my t-shirt + arm 
  • €35 - €44: A drink 
  • > €45: A dinner 
Targets:
  • € 360: We reached the minimum, thank you !
  • € 450: I wear fun socks 
  • € 550: I run with a cape  
  • € 650: I wear a tutu with my cape 
  • € 750: I add a wig to pass the finish-line  
  • Every additional €50 (I will find out when we get there haha - if yo  have target ideas feel free to share !)

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I'm running my first ever half marathon in April - the Royal Parks Half Marathon. 

Those of you who know me will know that I've never been a runner. During the first lockdown last year, I started running as a way to get out of the house and clear my mind. In recent months and to fill the void left by not being able to play my favourite sport football, I've pushed myself to start running longer distances and found myself enjoying it more. 

So, I wanted to use this opportunity to really push myself, achieve something and raise money for a great cause. I'll be running the half marathon for Unicef. Your donation will help to provide children life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection. 

I'd really appreciate any spare change you might have for this great cause. In return I promise live footage of my crippling state once I finally cross the finish line. 

Thanks in advance and here's hoping I make it through in one piece.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Hi everyone!

Lockdown sucks so I've signed up to run a half marathon. I've never been a runner (knees of an 80 year old) but have been getting into it since Covid hit so I thought I'd take the plunge and set myself a goal for 2021. 

I'm very happy to be running the race for Unicef. Unicef believes much the same stuff that I do: that every child should have access to clean water, food, health care, education, and a safe environment in which to grow up, regardless of where they were born. Your donation will help to provide children food, vaccinations, education and protection. 

Any donation, no matter how small, is welcome. Thank you for donating to such a good cause and looking out for those less fortunate than yourself!

Jared x

story:
Coronavirus is the biggest global crisis for children since World War Two. Unicef is launching its largest-ever appeal to help tackle the impact of coronavirus on children and families around the world.

Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations will help to limit the spread of the virus, protect keyworkers, and reduce the impact on some of the world’s most vulnerable children and families.

I am helping organise the Christmas event for the Working family Network – Annual Bring your family to work event.

This year  series of  online  activities have been organised  for  members of the network and other Barclays colleagues to enjoy the festive period

Barclays  colleagues– please
note details are on BarclaysNow and Working Family network site

  • 14th December – Christmas Pre-recorded Coding session 
  • 15th December – Christmas cards/ Crafts/Decorations
  • 16th December – Christmas Bake along video with Mrs Santa Claus
  • 17th December – Around the world Festive Quiz
  • 18th December – Santa story video

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The world is currently home to the largest generation of young people ever. 1.8 billion young people are on the verge of entering the workforce and 85% of the jobs that today's learners will be doing in 2030 have not been invented yet.

Collectively women and girls walk more than 200 million hours daily to collect water. This is time that could be spent in the classroom learning the digital skills they need for the future.

BT and Unicef are working in partnership to equip young people with the digital skills they need for the lives of tomorrow. By walking 5 miles a day for 1 week I am raising awareness of the significant barriers millions of young people face when trying to access education and demonstrating how BT and Unicef are working together to provide these young people with the digital skills they need for a successful future.
Please show your support for the BT Legal Global team by donating whatever you can spare to our challenge.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The Challenge 

Attempting a summit of a Kilimanjaro - The top-of Africa! Climbing to 5,895m over an 8  day trek.

Why Kilimanjaro?

It's the challenge and because it will be fun. That cliché of hikers/climbers "just because its there" is certainly true!   If we can raise some money for a worthy cause  - well that's got to be good!

100% of the money raised will go to the charity - this event is not organised by unicef and I do not have to raise any money to participate - I have organised the event and paid  for everything myself.

Training 

Completing 24 walks on the weekends leading upto Sept 2020 and the Kilimanjaro attempt -   "Beyond Bristol - 24 Country Walks - Robin Tetlow" (varying 7 - 11 mile walks) - a total of 203miles!

Please come and join me, walking is a social activity, and there is bound to be a pub!   Next Walk - Castle Combe, North Wraxall and Ford

Unicef

The world is currently home to the largest generation of young people ever. 1.8 billion young people are on the verge of entering the workforce and 85% of the jobs that today's learners will be doing in 2030 have not been invented yet.Collectively women and girls walk more than 200 million hours daily to collect water. This is time that could be spent in the classroom learning the digital skills they need for the future.BT and Unicef are working in partnership to equip young people with the digital skills they need for the lives of tomorrow. By walking 5 miles a day for 1 week I am raising awareness of the significant barriers millions of young people face when trying to access education and demonstrating how BT and Unicef are working together to provide these young people with the digital skills they need for a successful future.Please show your support by donating whatever you can spare to our challenge.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
It's time for the big one. The Marathon.

Although moderately fit and healthy today, many visiting this page will know that has not always been the case. Since my recovery, I have enjoyed swimming, cycling, rowing, climbing and dancing. Running? No!

Training is going to be tough, and having your support for the work of Unicef is exactly what I need to help me across that finish line. 

You can support me in one of 3 ways:

  1. Give me ideas of ways to raise money beyond only running
  2. Help me raise money by sharing my story with others or joining alongside me for a fundraising activity here
  3. Donating here on my JustGiving page directly to Unicef

My page donations will be sent direct to Unicef in a fast and secure way.

Unicef is the world's leading organisation working for children in danger across the globe. Even here at home, life for children can still be tough.

Almost 4 million UK children now live in poverty. Obesity and mental health problems are also rising and many experience violence, abuse and neglect everyday. So, here in the UK, Unicef are putting their years of experience working for children around the world into practice.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
This April my brother and I will be running the London Marathon.

 I have been running for 5 years and I never thought I would have an opportunity to take on such a  challenge. Sometimes you find a hobby that can push you to your limit which this will certainly do, as I currently only run 3-5 miles a couple times a week so the thought of running 26 miles is a frightening prospect.  However when I’m lacing up to run in the rain or cold winter morning’s  knowing that I have your support and kind donations will make the tough training schedule a little easier.

We’ll be running  for unicef who are a fantastic charity raising crucial funds for children all over the world including the UK. Unicef provide for children who need food, vaccinations, education and protection, giving a child the chance to grow up healthy, happy and safe.

A big thank you to everyone who donates it will make a difference to a child’s life and for supporting me on this epic journey I cannot thank you enough 😊

My page donations will be sent direct to the charity in a fast and secure way.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Hi there everyone, 

I hope you are all having wonderful days wherever you may be!!!

I have chosen to take part in the Royal Parks Half-Marathon as I want challenge myself physically. Most importantly however, I want to bring about progress and change with the money raised for Unicef and provide any and all resources we can to make the world a better place. With UNICEF donations, £630 can help provide water and sanitation to an entire village and improve lives. I am running this race for all those who deserve to stay hydrated and have access to water! I hope you will join me! 

Thanks for visiting and getting involved in my JustGiving page and I hope you feel you want to donate to this cause. 

Lucie

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Now my massively underwhelming football career has finally come to an end, it is time to tick off some items from my life to do list, and first up is the London Marathon in April.

My return to regular running has been tough and I spent most of the last 4-5 months with niggling injuries, but I am now in full training mode and am currently running about 26 miles a week....I just need to bring my time down a bit and fit those miles into a into a 4-5 hour period!

For those that are thinking of donating that haven't trained for a long distance event, you are not just sponsoring me for the actual day of the race, but for the training that goes into it. I personally think that the sacrifice of time and running in storms and the freezing cold is worth donating to. For those that know me well, I have even been getting up in the morning and running, which proves how seriously I am taking this as I am definitely not a morning person!!

I am running the event with my sister, who is a far better runner than I am, but doesn't have as many friends, so if you do feel like you could help her achieve her fundraising target as well then please click this link:

https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/alison-lindsey1

We have chosen UNICEF to raise money for as they are a fantastic organisation that help to make sure more of the world’s children are fed, vaccinated, educated and protected than any other organisation. They have done more to influence laws, policies and customs to help protect children than any other charity. I have been lucky enough to work closely with the team at UNICEF and they are an inspiring team that passionately believe in their cause.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Dear friends, 

In a very short time, the coronavirus outbreak has become an all-consuming global crisis, with unprecedented societal and business upheaval, particularly affecting those most vulnerable.

We would like you to share an initiative RDC is undertaking. We are offering FREE CONSULTATIONS over a simple phone or video call. With no obligation, we’d encourage you to then make a voluntary donation to UNICEF in place of any fees to RDC.

Unicef has an incredible global network of staff and volunteers which means they are uniquely placed to reach people in fearful, uncertain times. The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.

At RDC, we pride ourselves on the trusted advice we give to our clients, and I’m sure many of you will be using some quiet time to rethink strategy.

Our philosophy is that digital innovations should be shaped with customer interests at heart - to improve lifestyles. We help create a fair, agile, safe and open environment for a hyper-connected future.

Never before has this thinking been so relevant. I applaud you for the amazing work you have done over the years to keep your customers connected. But this does not come without responsibility - we are witnessing unprecedented demands on technology to keep in touch with loved ones, to keep business going and to protect the wellbeing of everyone.

Whether you’re thinking about rationalising, growing or if you’d like some executive mentoring, please reach out to us.

Stay safe, stay healthy and stay connected!

Warmest regards,

Arun Dehiri

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: Nicole and Luca's 100 mile bike ride!
story:
After becoming aware of the struggles of children living in refugee camps, our little girl, Nicole, age 9, decided that she wanted to help. One of the things we love most about Nicole, is her genuine concern and compassion for people less fortunate than herself. She was deeply saddened to learn of the terrible conditions that refugee children and their families find themselves in. After fleeing war zones or crisis in their own countries, many of these children are already undernourisheed, ill and weak. So the effects of coronavirus can be devastating.

Nicole and Luca have made it their mission to ride their  bikes a total distance of 100 miles between them, with a goal of raising £100. This is a huge challenge for them both, but especially little Luca who is only 3!

Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker on the frontline, including gloves, masks and coveralls, while just £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers.The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

Any donation would be greatly appreciated. Or should a donation not be possible, we would be so grateful if you could share our page.

Thank you so much for reading our story.

Nicole and Luca. xx
title: Our page to help a generation of children affected by Coronavirus

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I am fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.

Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker, including boots, gloves, masks and coveralls to help make sure that health workers are protected in situations where they may be at risk, while £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for 

The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.

Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.
title: My page to help children affected by Coronavirus

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The challenge is to walk 5 miles a day for 7 consecutive days during August. This relates to a week experiencing the types of distances millions of children are still walking daily to reach water. If participants want an additional challenge they can carry water or an equivalent weight to that which children are carrying (5kg, 10kg or 15kg). Get sponsored to take part, aim for a target of £1,500 per team of ten (£150 per individual).

The money raised from this challenge will go towards UNICEF's Children's Emergency Fund. Which provides crucial support for children in emergencies  wherever and whenever conflict or disaster strikes.

Millions of childrens lives are at risk today because of emergencies caused by conflict, natural disasters and climate change. They could be sudden, or may have been going on for a long time. You wont see many of them on the news, but every day these emergencies threaten the lives and futures of countless children.

Thank you so much for your support!

story:
Children around the world have their lives disrupted every day by violence, hunger, disease, conflict and disaster. Now, coronavirus has led to the biggest global crisis for vulnerable children and families since the Second World War. A whole generation of children are in danger.

I'm taking on the Great Big Soccer Aid Challenge to help vulnerable children and families stay safe, so they can grow up happy, healthy & able to play. 

Plus anything you donate will be tripled at no extra cost to you, thanks to the UK Government and Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, who are matching donations up until 6th October 2020!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
McWalkie Talkie 5K

Imaani McWalkie will be taking part in her first ever charity event and completing a 5km walk supported by her little sister Soraya (just started) McWalkie. She has been practicing all summer and has been eating lots of vegetables so she can be strong for her challenge. 

Jasmine and Michael McTalkie will be taking part in a one hour sponsored silence during the walk, with half an hour for Jasmine, followed by half an hour Michael (I know many of you would love to witness the 30 mins of pure and utter bliss during Michael's silence however rules of 6 apply so video footage will be available. 

We would love for you to be able to support us in any way you can on our first ever family fundraiser, by sharing or donating. We will be truly grateful for it all.

Children around the world have their lives disrupted every day by violence, hunger, disease, conflict and disaster. Now, coronavirus has led to the biggest global crisis for vulnerable children and families since the Second World War. A whole generation of children are in danger. We are taking on the Great Big Soccer Aid Challenge to help vulnerable children and families stay safe, so they can grow up happy, healthy & able to play. 

Plus anything you donate will be TRIPLED at no extra cost to you, thanks to the UK Government and Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, who are matching donations up until 6th October 2020!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
For those that know me, I do not run (don’t let the cover photo fool you, that was taken over 2 years ago). Of course,  it only makes sense that a half marathon in just over 4 months time is the perfect thing for me to do! 

So I'm running the 2021 Royal Parks Half Marathon in April *covid permitting* on behalf of Unicef. Unicef supports children all around the world, and donations help provide children with life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection. The target stands at £400, and I hope you will help me smash this target and help children worldwide. 

Many thanks to you all :) 

Fifi

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The world is currently home to the largest generation of young people ever. 1.8 billion young people are on the verge of entering the workforce and 85% of the jobs that today's learners will be doing in 2030 have not been invented yet.

Collectively women and girls walk more than 200 million hours daily to collect water. This is time that could be spent in the classroom learning the digital skills they need for the future.

BT and Unicef are working in partnership to equip young people with the digital skills they need for the lives of tomorrow. By walking 5 miles a day for 1 week I am raising awareness of the significant barriers millions of young people face when trying to access education and demonstrating how BT and Unicef are working together to provide these young people with the digital skills they need for a successful future.
Please show your support for the BT Legal Global team by donating whatever you can spare to our challenge.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The world is currently home to the largest generation of young people ever. 1.8 billion young people are on the verge of entering the workforce and 85% of the jobs that today's learners will be doing in 2030 have not been invented yet.

Collectively women and girls walk more than 200 million hours daily to collect water. This is time that could be spent in the classroom learning the digital skills they need for the future.

BT and Unicef are working in partnership to equip young people with the digital skills they need for the lives of tomorrow. By walking 5 miles a day for 1 week I am raising awareness of the significant barriers millions of young people face when trying to access education and demonstrating how BT and Unicef are working together to provide these young people with the digital skills they need for a successful future.

Please show your support by donating whatever you can spare to our challenge.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Running the London marathon is a daunting task and with just under 12 weeks until race day I feel I may have bitten off more than I can chew but, I ran the half marathon in Liverpool last year and it's only a little bit further than that so I should be fine. 

I've never been able to support UNICEF before but I know about the amazing work they do to support children all over the world from curing Polio in Pakistan and Nigeria to protecting children in Syria. Giving a child education, medical treatment and a quality of life are principles that UNICEF prides itself on and I want to do as much as I can do to help what they do. So please do take a look at their work and please give just a little bit towards helping these children. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. 

I always wanted to involve more in charity works especially for children who are less fortunate and those who are coping hard in depressing underdeveloped living conditions.

This idea to involve in charities has planted in my head since a very young age. It was influenced by my grandparents and parents brought me along in supporting the orphanages and disability children's homes where I had my first experience in helping someone I don't know at all yet put a smile on them. 

Since I came to London in 2010, I have become an active blood donor. I continue to give blood when I found out my blood is 'NEO' labelled (blood with mild cytomegalovirus which similar to the virus that causes chickenpox) which can only be transfused to newborn babies who need blood. It will be the 18th times this year. 💪 I wish to do as much as I can to support these innocent kids or babies. 

The fact that 1 little hour of 1 donation (470ml) allows to save up 3 adults or 12 infants lives is always mindblowing.

Kindly support me by donating and don't forget to share my page to your close ones and friends. I will be really meaningful to the children (especially those who are suffering HIV from their parents, who needed vaccinations, nutritions and clean water) Your support is much greater than my actions. I aim to raise £500 before the Royal Parks Half Marathon run in April 2021. Thank you!

Carrie

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: A photo to promote your area for staycations
story:
I am fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.

Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker, including boots, gloves, masks and coveralls to help make sure that health workers are protected in situations where they may be at risk, while £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for 

The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.

Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The challenge is to walk 5 miles a day for 7 consecutive days during August. This relates to a week experiencing the types of distances millions of children are still walking daily to reach water. If participants want an additional challenge they can carry water or an equivalent weight to that which children are carrying (5kg, 10kg or 15kg). Get sponsored to take part, aim for a target of £1,500 per team of ten (£150 per individual).

The money raised from this challenge will go towards UNICEF's Children's Emergency Fund. Which provides crucial support for children in emergencies  wherever and whenever conflict or disaster strikes.

Millions of childrens lives are at risk today because of emergencies caused by conflict, natural disasters and climate change. They could be sudden, or may have been going on for a long time. You wont see many of them on the news, but every day these emergencies threaten the lives and futures of countless children.

Thank you so much for your support!

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: We're climbing mount everest (on the stairs at home)
story:
We (Richard, Sarah, Laura, Lydia and Harvey) are jointly going to climb the height of Mount Everest on our stairs. At least one of us is in very bad shape two of us are 14 months old, so it might take us a while.

We chose UNICEF because the dire conditions that already exist in many places in the world (such as Yemen and Syrian refugee camps) are likely to be made immeasurably worse by the pandemic.

The rules for the adults are that it does not include normal stair use when moving around the house and climbing must be done in blocks of at least 5 flights.

For the babies, all stair use is included.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I am fundraising to help protect the children and families affected by the catastrophic explosions in Beirut, Lebanon on Tuesday 4 August. The explosions killed more than 100 people and injured 4,000. Around 300,000 people have been left without homes.

Unicef fears that children are among the casualties.

Already battling against coronavirus and economic instability, the disaster in Beirut adds to the crisis for the people of Lebanon. The pandemic has left hospitals overwhelmed and frontline workers exhausted.

Unicef is on the ground working closely with authorities and partners in Lebanon to respond to the needs of children, families and health workers.

Unicef are providing safe drinking water and hygiene kits for children and families in the city. They're helping set up counselling to support children who are experiencing trauma and those who have lost loved ones.

Please donate what you can to help. Thank you.

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: I'll give it a TRY(-athlon) for TRIPLE the money
story:
Donations to Unicef are being tripled matched (£1 raised --> £3) over Sept. So it feels like time to get my hands dirty/sweaty with a personal challenge.

Over Sept I'll be training for and completing my DIY sprint trialthlon around east London (27th of Sept: 750 swim, 20k cycle, 5k run). Given I don't own a bike and my open water swimming experience is a dip in Hampstead ponds, it's going to be grim.

Why? Unicef really is on the front line of the pandemic, already delivering over 7.5m masks, 2.8m respirators, 550k tests and being the organisation already preparing to lead the delivery of a vaccine in 92 countries. 

I would love to raise £500 so that £1500 can go towards the desperately needed more PPE, more sanitation equipment, more community workers, more remote learning programmes and hopefully distribution of a vaccine. So any help to get there would be amazing!!

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I’m humphrey and half way through this 33 day challenge I will be 10 years old! I raised £1300 last year and was always going to raise more, but things changed we couldn’t all play football together, but now i can do something.... please help me, help the children around the world who are not as fortunate as us....we might not have felt that fortunate recently but I just keep thinking about how these children must be feeling. Sad, lonely and scared....they didn’t  have online school lessons, clubs to return to, teachers who are excited to see them back at school...,,please donate whatever you can I know it’s financially hard for everyone right now but anything is better than what they have.

My plan is everyday to do something to raise money for example....do chores at home, help other people to do things around their house or outside or just be someone to talk to, sell my old chelsea kits, do a guess the amount of sweets in a jar, guess the name of a teddy and sell some cakes. I am going to do this for 33 days!!! ( I have more ideas and need some more too!)   Of course any donations would be gratefully received.

Children around the world have their lives disrupted every day by violence, hunger, disease, conflict and disaster. Now, coronavirus has led to the biggest global crisis for vulnerable children and families since the Second World War. A whole generation of children are in danger.I'm taking on the Great Big Soccer Aid Challenge to help vulnerable children and families stay safe, so they can grow up happy, healthy & able to play. Plus anything you donate will be tripled at no extra cost to you, thanks to the UK Government and Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, who are matching donations up until 6th October 2020.

Thank you for reading 

Humf xx

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I am fundraising for Unicef to support children in Indonesia who have been devastated by the earthquake and tsunami. 

Hundreds have been killed and many thousands severely affected by the devastating earthquake and tsunami that hit central Indonesia on Friday 29 September.The 7.4 magnitude earthquake hit Sulawesi at around 18:00 local time, and was followed by a tsunami with waves up to six metres high. 

Unicef is helping the Government of Indonesia to provide life-saving supplies and services to affected children and families. Unicef is especially concerned for the safety and wellbeing of children who have lost their homes, those who are sleeping rough, and those who have been separated from their families. Children also face extra risks to their health without nutritious food and clean water. Unicef is working closely with the government to support vulnerable children.

Please donate what you can to help the children of Indonesia.

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: Art exhibition at Transhed Tech, Cardiff
story:
Thank you so much Sinfonia Cymru for allowing me to be part of this amazing concert in Cardiff.  The event features powerful music to raise awareness to the climate challenge.  

My paintings will feature as part of the stage show visuals and will be exhibited and available for purchase to raise funds for Unicef's Cyclone Idai emergency appeal.

Cyclone Idai has triggered devastating floods across southern Africa. With almost 1 million children in danger, urgent support is needed.  Unicef is working with government and partners across the region to ensure children and families get the emergency supplies they need, and the vital support for the months ahead. 

On 30 March, Sinfonia Cymru will be performing #profitpeopleplanet written by my daughter Helen Wilson.  The music is a creative approach to raise awareness to the climate challenge.  

I am delighted that images taken from my paintings will be featured behind the musicians' platform during the performance.  The original paintings will also be exhibited on the evening.

More about the evening can be found at:

https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/peopleplanetprofit-tickets-49326860969

Anyone wishing to take a painting away from the exhibition can pay online at this page with all proceeds going in full to this important appeal.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
UPDATE!

I was meant to run the London Marathon in April 2020, but unfortunately that didn't happen. The October rescheduled marathon was also cancelled and I have now been given a new date - April 2022 (by which point I'll have been training for 2.5 years!)

In the meantime, I've done the VIRTUAL London marathon on 4th October 2020! I walked/ran it, joined by people for socially distanced legs. It took me 7 hours and thankfully I managed to dodge the rain, although I had very sore feet by the end. I am still fundraising, and now I've got a new date would love to raise £3000 for Unicef. It would mean the world if you could part with £5 to help save lives.


**********

On 12th September 2019, I received the most terrifying/exciting phone call ever - I have been chosen to run the London Marathon for Unicef! I'm one of only 30 runners out of their charity pool of 300+, and so honoured and delighted to have been picked. I'm really passionate about the literally lifesaving work that Unicef do, and have done lots of work with the charity through my role at school. They are such an amazing cause to be representing.

Quite simply, this is going to be the biggest challenge of my life. I've only been running for a couple of years, and have never attempted anything like this before. In addition to training, I have to raise £2000 in the next six months, including £1000 by New Year's Eve 2019! This is a marathon task in itself, and I need all the help I can get. Please spare a few pennies (or pounds, preferably!) to help this incredible cause.

Hannah x

Why Unicef?

Every day, millions of children and young people are facing violence, disease and hunger. This is a crisis on a global scale that it far too easy to forget. It is happening. Now.

It is too easy to be complacent. I’ve been fortunate to lead a comfortable, healthy life. I’ve had a good education, and grew up in a safe place surrounded by people I love, unlike millions of children in the chaos of war and poverty. 

Today, thousands of children will die from diseases that are easy to prevent. Thousands more will die because they don’t have the food they need to live and grow. And yet more will experience unspeakable violence. 50 million children have been uprooted from their homes and many are facing a freezing winter, often in a refugee camp or separated from their families. We have started to forget that refugees are human, and that refugee children are children first and foremost. 

Unicef ensures more of the world’s children are vaccinated, educated and protected than any other organisation.  They keep children safe by providing vaccines against deadly diseases and by promoting safe hygiene in communities around the world. They are the world’s largest supplier of emergency life-saving food for children, and campaign tirelessly to end violence against children.

I am lucky enough to work in a Unicef Rights Respecting school, where we have embedded children’s rights at the heart of our ethos. We teach our children about their rights, and encourage them to seek out injustices and make the world a better place for everyone. The Rights Respecting Award has transformed our school, and opened my eyes to the horrific experiences of children around the world, and the vital work of Unicef in combatting this.

No matter where they come from or where they’re going, all children deserve love, a safe home and hope for a happy future. 

By running, I will be able to help Unicef continue their vital work, helping to build a safer, healthier and happier world for children everywhere. My £2,000 in sponsorship could protect over 16,000 children from the crippling effects of polio.

What will your donation go toward?

£6 - provide rehydration salts to prevent 15 children from dying of diarrhoea 

£8 - 400 pencils for a school, or a good quality football for a group of children in a refugee camp to play with

£12 - warm hats, gloves and scarves for 4 children in the harsh Syrian winter

£13.50 - school supplies and backpacks for 5 children

£16 - equip a health worker with a vaccine cold box to protect children against polio, whooping cough and measles

£25 - help a midwife to safely deliver 12 babies 

£27 - provide over 600 children with clean water

£55 - train a health worker to provide mothers and children with nutritional and anti-malarial advice

£160 - school in a box to allow at least 40 children to continue learning in an emergency or war zone

£250 - protects over 2,000 children from the crippling effects of polio

£1500 - equip a midwife with all the equipment they need to safely deliver babies

£2000 - protect 16,000 children from polio

You can also donate to the Unicef UK London Marathon Team as a whole - all donations will go directly to Unicef UK. For more information, please visit www.unicef.org.uk. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thank you for vising this page and hopefully leaving a donation for a very worthwhile charity.


UNICEF ensures more of the world’s children are vaccinated, educated and protected than any other organisation. They have done more to influence laws and policies to help protect children than anyone else.

Right now, children in places like Myanmar, South Sudan and Yemen are caught up in violent conflict. They are fleeing war and disaster in greater numbers than at any time since World War 2.

And in countries such as Nepal and the Philippines, children have seen their communities destroyed by natural disasters like earthquakes, typhoons and flooding. However UNICEF also helps out young people much closer to home as well...

Like for so many children around the world, life for children in the UK can be tough as well. Almost 4 million live in poverty, obesity and mental health problems are rising, and many experience violence, abuse and neglect.

In the UK UNICEF puts years of experience working for children around the world into practice in the places that reach children day in, day out.

They work with the hospitals where they are born, the schools where they learn and grow and the services that support them to make sure that every child has the same chance to shine.

By walking 5 miles a day for 1 week I am raising awareness of the significant barriers millions of young people face when trying to access education and demonstrating how BT and Unicef are working together to provide these young people with the digital skills they need for a successful future.

Please show your support by donating whatever you can spare to our challenge.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Welcome to my fundraiser!

On October 11, 2020 I hope to run my first half marathon: the Royal Parks Half Marathon of London.

In order to secure a place in the marathon I have to raise 400 British Pounds (approx. 470 Euro's) for UNICEF before the big day. Will you help me reach my goal? This would make me very, very happy! 

Who will receive your donation? 

100% of your donation will directly go to UNICEF: a charity that provides medicine, food, water, education and protection to children around the world. 

Please do note that your donation is not refundable.

How will your donation help me?

Your donation will help me secure a place in the Royal Half Marathon of London. So, if not for UNICEF, do it for me ;-)

Why donate through this page?

Donating through this page is simple and secure. Once you donate, your money will be sent to UNICEF directly. It's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs. Your details are safe and you will not receive unwanted emails. It is also possible to donate anonymously. 

Have any questions? Please let me know!

Talisa

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: Gym Challenge - 100 Different exercises in 1 session
story: Sahir and I will be fundraising to help protect the children and families affected by the catastrophic explosions in Beirut, Lebanon on Tuesday 4 August. The explosions killed more than 100 people and injured 4,000. Around 300,000 people have been left without homes. Unicef fears that children are among the casualties. Already battling against coronavirus and economic instability, the disaster in Beirut adds to the crisis for the people of Lebanon. The pandemic has left hospitals overwhelmed and frontline workers exhausted. Unicef is on the ground working closely with authorities and partners in Lebanon to respond to the needs of children, families and health workers. Unicef are providing safe drinking water and hygiene kits for children and families in the city. They're helping set up counselling to support children who are experiencing trauma and those who have lost loved ones. Please donate what you can to help. Thank you.
