charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Welcome to my fundraiser!

- Who will receive your donation? 

100% of your donation will directly go to Unicef: a charity that provides medicine, food, water, education and protection to children around the world. 

- Why donating through this page? 

Donating through this page is simple and secure. Once you donate, your money will be sent to Unicef directly. It's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs. Your details are safe and you will not receive unwanted emails. It is also possible to donate anonymously. 

- How will your donation help me? 

Your donation will help me secure a place at the Royal Parks Half Marathon of London, on April 11, 2021. This would be my first half marathon: so if not for Unicef, do it for me ;-) 

Have any questions? Please let me know! 


Below you can find more details on how I came across the idea to join the Royal Parks Half: 

Dear reader,

The global pandemic has been disrupting our modes of life for months now, and once again the most innocent among us have been severely affected: I am talking about children. I do not mean to sound overly dramatic - I will leave that rhetoric to some crybaby politicians, and stick to my straightforward communication style instead... So, let's face reality: because of this virus, children around the world have been affected in multiple ways. 

In a direct way, the virus could result in loss of parental care due to death, illness or separation, thereby placing children at heightened risk for violence, neglect or exploitation. More indirectly, many of the prevention and control measures have resulted in disruptions to the reporting and referral mechanisms of child protection services. For children in residential care, a lack of capacity and resources has resulted in a rapid closure of such facilities, with children being returned to families without proper preparation. For children in street situations, access to help and support services is likely to be even more challenging. Moreover, measures to contain the virus have affected delivery of vital support and treatment services as well as contact with informal support networks. The mental health of children has also been threatened, as it is incredibly challenging to stay at home and keep up with virtual learning without the proper resources to do so. And these are just some aspects of a broader dynamic that can't be narrowed down to a few lines. For this reason I will share some links at the bottom of the page, please do inform yourself on what is going on.

So what? To put it simply, this means that more children need more help now, our help. 

Under lockdown, while studying and working in front of a screen, I often found my mind lingering on the following dilemma: "What can I do to overcome the current limitations and significantly help those affected children?". If before the pandemic I could easily volunteer and pioneer for children's rights in a variety of ways as I have often done, the current restrictions have made it way more challenging to reach out to those in need. Thus I realised that I would have had to make the best out of the only two tools still available to fundraise,  which are internet and about one hour of outdoor exercise per day (aka my daily spark of joy) to contribute to an initiative that will be life changing for many children. 

This is how I decided to run the 2021 Royal Parks Half Marathon and fundraise for Unicef. Unicef needs our help to support children around the world. Your donation will help to provide children life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection. Help me smash their fundraising targets and help children worldwide! 

Your donation will make a difference, just as every single vote in the latest American presidential election has lead to a great milestone for democracy and gender equality. Please become a part of this donation now by contributing with what ever you can to my fundraiser for Unicef UK. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. 

Thank you. 

Sincerely,

Rebecca


Links 

https://www.mentalhealth.org.uk/publications/impacts-lockdown-mental-health-children-and-young-people

https://www.ox.ac.uk/news/2020-08-19-study-finds-significant-increase-child-parent-violence-lockdown

https://www.theguardian.com/education/2020/nov/10/children-regressing-and-struggling-mentally-in-lockdown-says-ofsted

https://www.thelancet.com/article/S0140-6736(20)31648-2/fulltext

https://www.unicef.org.uk

story:
The world is currently home to the largest generation of young people ever. 1.8 billion young people are on the verge of entering the workforce and 85% of the jobs that today's learners will be doing in 2030 have not been invented yet.

Collectively women and girls walk more than 200 million hours daily to collect water. This is time that could be spent in the classroom learning the digital skills they need for the future.

BT and Unicef are working in partnership to equip young people with the digital skills they need for the lives of tomorrow. By walking 5 miles a day for 1 week I am raising awareness of the significant barriers millions of young people face when trying to access education and demonstrating how BT and Unicef are working together to provide these young people with the digital skills they need for a successful future.

Please show your support by donating whatever you can spare to our challenge.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Hello and thank you for visiting my JustGiving page.

I was delighted to learn I had been selected for a place in the London Marathon 2020, fundraising for BT’s charity partner, UNICEF.

UNICEF is the United Nations Children’s Fund, working in the world’s toughest places to reach the most disadvantaged children and adolescents – and to protect the rights of every child, everywhere.

As a keen runner this will be my 5th Marathon and the opportunity to run for Team UNICEF in the London Marathon is an exciting challenge, whilst raising funds for this vital cause. The most difficult part will be maintaining the  commitment to my training plan, 5 days a week, in the cold and grey wintry months ahead  in preparation for the gruelling 26.2 mile test.

If you would like to support me, your donations would be gratefully received and very much appreciated as each contribution will make such a big difference in the fight to save children’s lives. 

Thank you

Andrew Dell’Anno


Thanks for your support with my London Marathon JustGiving challenge!

My page donations will be sent direct to the charity in a fast and secure way. Its efficient, saves time and cuts costs for the charity. Let's do this!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Hi All,

So it's that time again! I am asking for you to support me as I train and then run a half marathon for UNICEF.

As many of you know I have been doing fundraising events for UNICEF years and years. They are an incredible charity that is always there helping children in need globally, from providing life saving food, vaccines, blankets and clothing to shelter, protecting them as best they can against climate emergency, education, and a future to look forward to.

Having visited a UNICEF funded school while I was in Fiji, there is nothing more rewarding than seeing so many small happy faces, just filled with joy at the prospect of being at school. And it let me know that my faith in UNICEF is not even a little bit misplaced.

Anything you can give would be fantastic, whether its £1, £5 or £50!

Also PLEASE gift aid it if you are a UK taxpayer :)

MUCH LOVE

xx

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Since the start of 2017, Autovista Group has supported UNICEF.

Over the past three years, thanks to the enthusiasm, support and hard work of Autovista Group employees we have raised over £150,000, ensuring that children across the world have access to education, healthcare and a safe environment in which to grow and develop.

Coronavirus is affecting children’s lives in almost every country. Unicef is helping to tackle the impact of this new virus around the world by providing essential supplies, healthcare and information to people so that communities can effectively protect themselves from the harmful effects of the virus.

It has estimated that over £500 million is needed to help it scale up support for efforts to contain the coronavirus outbreak and provide support to countries with weaker health systems.

In 2020, the Group is aiming to raise a further £25,000 for UNICEF to help them in this initiative. Last year, our staff ran, climbed, baked, knitted… for UNICEF. This year, we are set to do it again. Please get behind them and help us raise vital funds to support UNICEF. Thank you!

story:

Delightfully illustrated by Rhea Mehta, the book is available to buy as an ebook or paperback here :

We are raising money for UNICEF and your contribution will make an impact, whether you donate £5 or £500. Every little bit helps. Thank you for your support.

Sincerely,
Snehal Khanna

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The challenge is to walk 5 miles a day for 7 consecutive days during August. This relates to a week experiencing the types of distances millions of children are still walking daily to reach water. If participants want an additional challenge they can carry water or an equivalent weight to that which children are carrying (5kg, 10kg or 15kg). Get sponsored to take part, aim for a target of £1,500 per team of ten (£150 per individual).

The money raised from this challenge will go towards UNICEF's Children's Emergency Fund. Which provides crucial support for children in emergencies  wherever and whenever conflict or disaster strikes.

Millions of childrens lives are at risk today because of emergencies caused by conflict, natural disasters and climate change. They could be sudden, or may have been going on for a long time. You wont see many of them on the news, but every day these emergencies threaten the lives and futures of countless children.

Thank you so much for your support!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Three footballs, one goal, over 3 days - this August bank holiday weekend. Come one, come all - beat the goalie or if you can't come to my front yard simply DONATE! Why all these 3's?? It's because for every pounds donated it'll be TRIPLED at no extra cost to you. What a great success for children everywhere!!

Children around the world have their lives disrupted every day by violence, hunger, disease, conflict and disaster. Now, coronavirus has led to the biggest global crisis for vulnerable children and families since the Second World War. A whole generation of children are in danger. I'm taking on the Great Big Soccer Aid Challenge to help vulnerable children and families stay safe, so they can grow up happy, healthy & able to play. Plus anything you donate will be tripled at no extra cost to you, thanks to the UK Government and Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, who are matching donations up until 6th October 2020!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
My daughter Beatrix (8 years old) said she wanted to help children who are poor, starving and struggling. There are so many that need our help.

Spurred on by participating in a marathon over 7 days to raise money for others over the lockdown, she asked if we could do 100km in a month and help more people. 

Now I'm no writer at all but please understand how overwhelming it is to pick a charity, a cause. Where do we start? I wanted to help people that were unable to help themselves - children. But the need is all over the world so who, where? 

We chose Unicef - the world's leading organisation in keeping children out of danger. Recent events have been so difficult but elsewhere the threat to life in unimaginable. 

Please support us, no matter how small, to help this amazing charity. To help small peoples lives so my small person will know that small matters. It can change the world. 

The following is a statement from Unicef...... 

We are fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker on the frontline, including gloves, masks and coveralls, while just £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers.The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.
title: 100km in July - Raising money to help children affected by Coronavirus

Who'd have thought it?! Just over a year ago I couldn't run 5K but I saw an ad asking for runners and I'm so loving running that I thought why not give it a go?! 

I will be fundraising for Unicef who need our help to support children around the world. 

Your donation will help to provide children life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection. 

Please help me smash their fundraising targets and help children worldwide. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. 

Thank you.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I am fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.
Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker on the frontline, including gloves, masks and coveralls, while just £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers.
The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.
Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The challenge is to walk 5 miles a day for 7 consecutive days during August. This relates to a week experiencing the types of distances millions of children are still walking daily to reach water. If participants want an additional challenge they can carry water or an equivalent weight to that which children are carrying (5kg, 10kg or 15kg). Get sponsored to take part, aim for a target of £1,500 per team of ten (£150 per individual).

The money raised from this challenge will go towards UNICEF's Children's Emergency Fund. Which provides crucial support for children in emergencies  wherever and whenever conflict or disaster strikes.

Millions of childrens lives are at risk today because of emergencies caused by conflict, natural disasters and climate change. They could be sudden, or may have been going on for a long time. You wont see many of them on the news, but every day these emergencies threaten the lives and futures of countless children.

Thank you so much for your support!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The DM team is taking on My RideLondon to help children and families affected by the explosions in Beirut.

According to latest reports, the death toll could be as high as 100 with 4,000 wounded and over 300,000 people displaced. UNICEF is concerned that children are among the casualties and we are aware that those who survived are traumatized and under shock.

UNICEF’s team in Beirut has not been spared. One of our colleagues lost his spouse, seven of our staff were mildly injured and dozens of personnel’s homes were damaged. Most of our staff- as are most people in Lebanon- are in a state of shock.

We stand in solidarity with everyone affected, and hope to raise as much as we can so Unicef can continue to be there, on the ground, to help children and families affected by this shocking event. 

🚲Please donate what you can to our many many miles we aim to cycle as a team!🚲

charity.name: Unicef UK
story: Hello friends. As most of you know, my Father was Lebanese and I have lots of family in Beirut. It has been devastating to see the effects of the explosions that killed and injured so many, and left an estimated 300,000+ people without homes. I have been left feeling helpless but knew I had to do something, and this is all I could think of. I am running 100km in September to try and encourage my friends to donate to Unicef to help protect the children and families affected. Unicef are responding to the needs of children, families and health workers by providing safe drinking water and hygiene kits as well as offering counselling to support children who are experiencing trauma and those who have lost loved ones. Please give what you can, however large or small. Thank you so so much. BIG LOVE X

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: Raising money for people affected by the Cyclone Adai. If we reach £2000 shave my hair off, and hopefully donate that too.
story:
Our planet is facing a climate emergency. The problem is the worst impact of climate change are being felt by the most vulnerable and least responsible.

I'm fundraising for Unicef's Cyclone Idai emergency appeal. Cyclone Idai has triggered devastating floods across southern Africa. With almost 1 million children in danger, we urgently need your support. Unicef is working with government and partners across the region to ensure children and families get the emergency supplies they need and the vital support for the months ahead. Please support my fundraising so that Unicef can respond to children and families with life-saving support. Fundraise for children affected by Cyclone Idai today.

If I reach my target (£500) I will be shaving my head to donate it to the Little Princess Trust who have been helping children and young people since 2006. They provide free real-hair wigs to children and young people, up to 24 years, who have lost their own hair through cancer treatment or other conditions. Their greatest need is hair donations 16” (41cm) or longer.

It is something I’ve been planning to do for the past couple of years. I’ve been allowing my hair to grow, keeping it strong and healthy as possible. Now I find it right to give it away to someone during their difficult and painful time in their lives. My hair will grow back but for many, it won’t. My hair varies in the length of 27” (70cm).

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
UNICEF is working with the government of Indonesia to support children and families affected by the tsunami that has hit Palu on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi. The appeal will help the organisation to mobilise emergency supplies and workers and to address the urgent humanitarian needs in affected areas.

Since the start of 2017, Autovista Group has been supporting UNICEF UK and is keen to raise as much money as possible at this critical time to help the charity's emergency efforts.

Please try and donate as much as you are able. EVERY pound you donate with go straight to UNICEF and Autovista Group has promised to match anything staff raise pound for pound.

A huge thank you for your support in helping us to raise funds for a very important and worthwhile cause.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page and supporting me on this (bound to be) very bumpy ride! 

I have been dying to run the London Marathon for years, and what better cause to run it for. Unicef is working to make a difference for children all over the world. They provide food, education and emergency protection while making sure every child has the right to be exactly that, a child. The work they do has changed the lives of so many children, please help me to help them change the lives of even more.

Training for the marathon is going be a series of blood, sweat and tears - I'm going to have to dig VERY deep - so please show some love & support! 

Thanks again xxx

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. 

Completed the Virtual London Marathon on Sunday, 4th October 2020 with the aim of keeping on raising and pushing on ready for the real thing on the 5th October 2021 😄

Edit: Evie is completing the 2.6 challenge in aid of UNICEF UK on the 26th April 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic. She is going to run 2.6 miles with daddy locally and making sure she follows social distancing. Evie is aiming to raise £100 pounds on top of daddy's target!!

I am incredibly honoured and privileged to be given the opportunity to run the London Marathon 2020 in aid of UNICEF. I chose this charity because of the incredible work they do with children, and as a teacher I know the importance of giving children the opportunities to be able to thrive.

Unicef was created in 1946 to help protect children after World War 2, the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child is the basis of all of their exceptional work. Today they continue to help children get vaccinated, educated and influence laws and policies to help protect children all around the world.
Right now, children in places like Myanmar, South Sudan and Yemen are caught up in violent conflict. They are fleeing war and disaster in greater numbers than at any time since World War 2. And in countries such as Nepal and the Philippines, children have seen their communities destroyed by natural disasters like earthquakes, typhoons and flooding.

In a humanitarian emergency, Unicef responds rapidly and stay as long as they are needed 💪🙌👍. 

Having run only 2 marathons before; the experts tell me I need to give myself around a 24 week training schedule. So now I'm on a mission running numerous paths, found various places I never knew existed and realised that nothing is more fun than running in the heavy wind and rain 😅.

Reading the London Marathon website, it states “Ethiopian legend Kenenisa Bekele is set to take on Sir Mo Farah and Eliud Kipchoge in a stunning Virgin Money London Marathon elite men’s field”, disappointingly there is no mention of myself, its like they feel I don’t have a chance 😂.

Any way here’s to, pasta, blisters and chaffing and please do donate as much as you can to such a worthwhile cause 👍🙌💪.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Hi, my name is Chris and in April 2020 I will be representing Unicef in the London Marathon. I will be one person in a team of 33, among over 40,000 runners completing the 26.2 mile course.

I am running to raise awareness of the work that Unicef completes not only in the United Kingdom, but also across the whole globe. Unicef is an international charity, but with one focus. Protecting and promoting the rights of children.

As a father of one and a part-time primary school teacher, who works in an inner London Unicef rights respecting school, I have long been a supporter and promoter of Unicef's work, but now feel it is time make a bigger contribution.

In the UK alone Unicef helps over 2 million children, from hospital wards to school play-grounds each year. Unicef are hoping to increase this number to 6 million children in the next 5 years.

Across the world children’s lives, rights and liberties are in danger every day. Unicef is there to help them.

12p protects one child from polio.

£5 buys a blanket to keep a baby warm in a hospital, day-care centre or refugee camp.

£10 purchases exercise books, pens, pencils, textbooks and other school things to support the education of a child for a whole year.

£19.50 provides mosquito nets that protects 7 families from malaria.

£136 donation provides school equipment for 40 children to continue with their education during an emergency or natural disaster with Unicef’s school in a box.

£1,063 is the cost of a temporary school or health centre for children who have survived a natural disaster, war or displacement to have a safe space to learn and play or receive medical care.

Any amount donated will make a massive difference to children’s lives here in Great Britain and across the world. My goal is to raise £2000.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The world is currently home to the largest generation of young people ever. 1.8 billion young people are on the verge of entering the workforce and 85% of the jobs that today's learners will be doing in 2030 have not been invented yet.

Collectively women and girls walk more than 200 million hours daily to collect water. This is time that could be spent in the classroom learning the digital skills they need for the future.

BT and Unicef are working in partnership to equip young people with the digital skills they need for the lives of tomorrow. By walking 5 miles a day for 1 week I am raising awareness of the significant barriers millions of young people face when trying to access education and demonstrating how BT and Unicef are working together to provide these young people with the digital skills they need for a successful future.
Please show your support for the BT Legal Global team by donating whatever you can spare to our challenge.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
The world is currently home to the largest generation of young people ever. 1.8 billion young people are on the verge of entering the workforce and 85% of the jobs that today's learners will be doing in 2030 have not been invented yet.

Collectively women and girls walk more than 200 million hours daily to collect water. This is time that could be spent in the classroom learning the digital skills they need for the future.

BT and Unicef are working in partnership to equip young people with the digital skills they need for the lives of tomorrow. By walking 5 miles a day for 1 week I am raising awareness of the significant barriers millions of young people face when trying to access education and demonstrating how BT and Unicef are working together to provide these young people with the digital skills they need for a successful future.
Please show your support for the BT Legal Global team by donating whatever you can spare to our challenge.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Hey Everyone!


I'm excited, grateful, and proud to be a member for UNICEF's UK's 2020 London Marathon Team. I will be one person on a team of 33, covering 26.2 miles through the streets of London with 40,000 other runners in April. As a former temporary resident of London, going back to the old stomping grounds and running on behalf of such a wonderful organization and its mission means so much to me.

 As many of you know, service and running has played such an integral role in my life growing up in this melting pot called New York. A quote that I try my best to live by is the Ignatian Way's "men and women for others".  Working with UNICEF and learning about their goals and charity has made all these passions come together and has made all these miles worth it! 

In April, I'll run to support UNICEF and their mission to protect & promote the rights of every child.UNICEF gets things done.  In 2018, they supported birth in health facilities for 27 million babies, delivered crucial vaccinations to 65.5 million children, provided education for 12 million children, and treated 4 million children with severe acute malnutrition.  They are relentless and won’t stop until the world is a safe place for all children.  UNICEF is supported entirely through donations and we can all have an impact on a child’s life. 

This is what funds like that will allow UNICEF to do for children
  • 12p protects one child from polio
  • £5 buys a blanket to keep a baby warm in a hospital, day-care centre or refugee camp
  • £10 purchases exercise books, pens, pencils, textbooks and other school things to support the education of a child for a whole year
  • £19.50 provides mosquito nets to protect 7 families from deadly malaria
  • £136 provides school equipment for 40 children to continue with their education during an emergency or natural disaster
  • £257 allows the installation of a water pump to provide clean, safe water to a school or a whole village or community
  • £1,063 is the cost a temporary school or health centre for children who have survived a natural disaster, war or displacement to have a safe space to learn and play or receive medical care.
I sincerely appreciate any contributions you make to this cause. This will be an amazing experience and am very excited to be racing for UNICEF and their cause. 


Thank you!

Eddie

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: Soccer Aid Challenge - Freddie and Warwick
story:
Freddie decided he wanted to run with daddy. Freddie’s target is 1KM EACH DAY for a week.

On top of Freddie’s running, EVERY DAY I am going to run ONE MORE KM, till I drop. The target is 20 days.

Day 1 - 1km

Day 2 - 2km

Day 3 - 3km etc

Children around the world have their lives disrupted every day by violence, hunger, disease, conflict and disaster. Now, coronavirus has led to the biggest global crisis for vulnerable children and families since the Second World War. A whole generation of children are in danger. I'm taking on the Great Big Soccer Aid Challenge to help vulnerable children and families stay safe, so they can grow up happy, healthy & able to play. Plus anything you donate will be tripled at no extra cost to you, thanks to the UK Government and Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, who are matching donations up until 6th October 2020!

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: Online Christmas Present Car Boot Sale
story:
I am fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.
Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker on the frontline, including gloves, masks and coveralls, while just £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers.
The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.
Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Both my grandfathers were pillars in their own communities I stand proud and  I also have my own community interest company Work works training solutions. Our company works extremely closely with young people whom which are suffering from social and economic deprivation. Our aim is to give young people the ability to be independent from the benefit system and eventually have a stake in society, Empowering them to be respected members of their own community by giving them the skills, mentoring and qualifications that is also vital and necessary in the times we live in today.

I’m running for my family and all people who are in need at the 2020 Royal Parks Half Marathon. This I will be fundraising for Unicef. Unicef needs your help to support children around the world. Your donation will help to provide children life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection. Help me smash their fundraising targets and help children worldwide. Your donation will make a difference. Please donate what ever you can to my fundraiser for Unicef UK. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. 


Thank you


Mem Zeki ❤️

With your help, we can build a safer world for children. I believe these issues are of the upmost importance in today's world

Thank you very much for taking the time to look at this page!

Dillon Fisher.

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
eventName: DC Walk for Medecins Sans Frontieres
story:
MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. We are raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease.  

Our fundraising team is covering the distance between our London and Paris hotels (430KM) in a combined effort - each team member will be walking 10 km in their local area on the 20th June 2020.  We calculated our route based on passing by Calais, where MSF is working hard to save lives in "The Jungle", battling this epidemic and stopping the spread of the virus.

How you can help:- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe. However, any amount, no matter how small, will make a huge difference. Thank you.
title: Support MSF's teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis
pageSummary: We are work colleagues from UK and France walking because together we can help raise funds for this cause.

pageSummaryWhy: together we can help raise funds for this cause.

story:
Please donate a minimum of £10 per sheep - you can bet on as many sheep as you want...

Please write the name of your sheep in the donation comment so we can then pull the winning name out of the hat after the race.

The Winner of the race will receive a box of wine from www.bibwine.co.uk and a bag of sweets

Your money will go straight to supporting MSF:

Right now, Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the new coronavirus disease.

Their teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck.

They are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives.
title: Support Medecins Sans Frontieres

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
eventName: Colt support MSF Coronavirus Crisis Appeal
story:
Over the next two weeks, we’ll be raising awareness of one global charity that is making a real difference during the Covid-19 pandemic. Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is an independent charity working to save people’s lives in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics in over 70 countries across the world. Their Coronavirus Crisis Appeal is providing urgently needed medical care and support to counter this new disease; sending medical teams where they are needed most, protecting healthcare staff and providing medical supplies.

Can you help support our chosen charity?

We would be extremely grateful if you could donate any amount of money you’re able to, to this very worthwhile cause. Here’s what our money collectively will go to at MSF:

  • €32/£28 pays for protective plastic goggles for four doctors
  • €66/£58 pays for sterile gloves for 30 medics
  • €126/£110 pays for five protective suits to keep staff safe

It is also important to add that we are all facing a tough time right now so you are not expected to give anything – it is only if you want to and are able to.

Colt's Executive Leadership Team have also agreed to match up to €15,000 so we could raise an incredible €30,000! And even the smallest donations make a big difference – if everyone at Colt gave just €3 we would reach our target easily.

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
As the number of cases for the moment slowly decrease across Europe, it is vital that our attention remains focused on those most vulnerable in countries afflicted by conflict or widespread poverty.  Advanced modern European healthcare systems struggled to contain Covid-19. It is only a matter of time before Covid-19 completely overwhelms states with weaker infrastructure. 

MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives.

I have set myself the challenge of running 100km in 15 days to raise funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. So if you got a fiver lying around from that pint you didn't manage to buy due to quarantine, please donate. Here is a rough idea of where that money goes to: 

- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.

- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.

- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.

- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.

I know that the fact these donations go towards medical equipment might appear less important than essential items such as food. However, Covid-19 risks dismantling all the pre-existing services present in poorer countries that prevent millions from dying of hunger and curable diseases. It is essential therefore that all countries are helped to overcome Covid-19 if there is any hope in keeping existing schemes effective in combating poverty. 

Thank you so much for any donation xxx

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Ordinary people are bearing the brunt of an increasingly brutal conflict in Yemen.  After five years of war, more than 80 percent of the population, 24 million people, need humanitarian assistance.

Médecins Sans Frontières activities in Yemen are among their most extensive worldwide, but the needs remain huge while the healthcare system is even weaker than it was in 2015, when conflict erupted.

MSF is running the only COVID-19 treatment centre for the whole of southern Yemen. Their teams are working around the clock to provide the best level of care that they can.

£10 could provide a weeks worth of dressings for serious wounds 
£15 could provide two leg splints to treat fractures
£30 could pay for 40 oxygen masks 

Thank you so much for whatever you can give.

story:
The new coronavirus disease, COVID-19, has spread to more than 200 countries around the world. MSFs medical teams are responding to the pandemic on multiple fronts. In Europe, MSF is providing support to health authorities in Italy, Spain, France, Belgium and Switzerland. 


In many of the other countries where they work, MSF teams are working with local health authorities to prepare for the impact of COVID-19. Even during this crisis, MSF are determined to keep their regular medical programmes running for the tens of thousands of patients they support. 


I'm raising funds to help support MSF's medical teams on the ground to respond to the coronavirus crisis. Your donation can make a big difference:


- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.

- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.

- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.

- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.


Thank you.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
For many years, I ran races (mostly half marathons, but some shorter distances, and some full marathons) to raise money for worthy causes.

My middle-aged body no longer wants to run, but my compassionate heart and frustrated (at the state of the world) soul was looking for another way to contribute to tikkun olam (the fixing of the world).

I found it with the L2B challenge - a long hike south from London, and the opportunity to support Doctors Without Borders, also known as Medecins Sans Frontieres  in French and Medici Senza Frontiere in Italian (MSF).  MSF is a remarkable organization.  When we talk about the numerous crises in the world, many people have shared the famous quote attributed to Mr. Fred Rogers (of American children's television fame), "My mother would say to me, ‘Look for the helpers. You will always find people who are helping.’ To this day, especially in times of disaster, I remember my mother’s words, and I am always comforted by realizing that there are still so many helpers — so many caring people in this world.”  MSF embodies exactly those types of helpers - all over the world to so many people in need.

I have tricked some other adventuresome friends into training and participating with me.  So this Memorial Day weekend we are headed to the UK to complete the "first half challenge": 

https://www.ultrachallenge.com/london-2-brighton-challenge/challenge-options

I am going to send this around in conjunction with my 45th birthday this year.  Any contribution is much appreciated, and if you are interested in participating, let me know!  Because the event is in the UK, that is the specific branch of MSF I am fundraising for, but you can also read more about them on their international and USA sites and the blurb below.

I picked this photo because it is the closest I have looked to being the kind of badass world saver that works for MSF.  Thanks for taking the time to read this!

This year, MSF UK is celebrating a special anniversary. Over the past 25 years, MSF UK has sent 4,329 experienced medical and logistical staff to respond to emergencies around the world. To celebrate this milestone we are dedicating our special occasion to MSF's life-saving work by asking our friends and family to donate to MSF, instead of buying a gift this year.

For the below links and videos, right click and then open in a new tab or window:

https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/

https://www.msf.org/

MSF in 40 seconds

How MSF Does It

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
From Wednesday, people across the UK will be able to go outside for unlimited exercise and I for one am incredibly jealous.

Anyone who knows me knows that I am a full-blown wellness w*nker and workout between three and five times a week. Right now, my workouts are a little more tricky to achieve as I am one of the millions of Brits on the Government's shielding list.

I was born with a ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, a horseshoe kidney and von Willebrand's disease. For the uninitiated, that means I have a hole in my heart, my kidneys are joined together and not quite as functional as your average pair and I have a blood clotting disorder that means my blood doesn't clot quickly enough. If you listen carefully, you might be able to hear a chorus of tiny violins round about now. 

Despite that all sounding very scary, I am generally well and use fitness as a tool to keep things that way, but the comorbidities of all these conditions mean that I am more at risk of Covid-19 than most my age with my fitness level. 

I've been told in no uncertain terms to stay inside for 12 weeks from the date I received confirmation from the Government that I was on this list. I make that until 30th June. 

After being challenged to run a 5k inside the house, I had an idea...

Here's what I want to do:

I will complete a daily fitness challenge that I can do, at home every day that everyone else is allowed to go outside and I am not in aid of Médecins Sans Frontières, so that they can keep providing treatment against Covid-19 around the world. 

What kind of challenges? Well, here are some rules:

  1. It has to be something I can do in the house or in my parents' tiny garden
  2. It can't be something that takes all day - I am fortunate enough to still be working from home so need to fit it around my shifts
  3. It has to be something I don't need to buy any equipment for. All I have here at the moment is a TRX, a yoga mat and a couple of (not very good) resistance bands. 
  4. I will try almost anything but don't have to get it right. I am human and I just really cannot get to grips with cartwheels for example.

Want to challenge me to try something? Leave a comment with your donation and I will see what I can do.

So far on my list, I have a headstand, the t-shirt challenge, and trying to hold crow pose for more than 10 seconds so I will be in need of some inspiration!

About MSF:

MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. 

I'm raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. 

Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. 

 MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF is deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives. 

How you can help:

- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.
- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.
- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.
- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.

Thank you.

We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
eventName: Zwift Tour for All Run and Ride
story:
Last September I damaged a disc in my back and have been on a slow recovery back to being able to run and ride. This challenge would have been easy 12 months ago. The Zwift Tour for All https://zwift.com/uk/tfaride is a charity event I the virtual world and I thought is might be a good opportunity to contribute to this global crisis in a little way. If I complete all 10 stages I will have run 24km and riden 138km with 1849m of ascent. Nothing to some people but a challenge for me along with fitting it in around work. 

Doctors without Borders is the chosen charity of the event and I've chosen to try and raise a bit more because I feel that where you live shouldn't be a barrier to getting the help you need. Our NHS is fantastic and under so much pressure but there are so many people in the world who have no access to health care normally never mind during this crisis. I'm raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck.

Thank you.

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
I'm raising funds to support the Doctors Without Borders (Medecins Sans Frontieres - MSF) medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support for some of the world's most vulnerable people, such as people living in refugee camps. 

For every £10 raised, I will be running, cycling or walking 1km dressed as a Zebra! So, if you would like to see a zebra come by, please consider sponsoring me =)

Amongst other things, MSF will be using the donations to provide staff with PPE: £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves; £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors; £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics; and £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe. You can find out more about MSF's vital work here: https://www.msf.org.uk/

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Ordinary people are bearing the brunt of an increasingly brutal conflict in Yemen.

After five years of war, more than 80 percent of the population, 24 million people, need humanitarian assistance.

MSFs activities in Yemen are among their most extensive worldwide, but the needs remain huge while the healthcare system is even weaker than it was in 2015, when conflict erupted.

MSF is running the only COVID-19 treatment centre for the whole of southern Yemen. Their teams are working around the clock to provide the best level of care that they can.

How your support makes an impact

£10 could provide eight dressings for wounds 
£17 could provide two leg splints to treat fractures 
£31 could pay for 40 oxygen masks 
£97 could pay for a physiotherapist for one day 

Thank you so much.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
The Fourth International VR Awards, the largest international awards ceremony celebrating outstanding achievement in the virtual reality industry, has announced its finalists.

After announcing their partnership with VR Chat to host this year's ceremony, in which tickets sales are now live, the VR Awards received hundreds of incredible quality nominations; those who make the finalist list are only the very best VR projects submitted from across the world.

We are asking every ticket sale to contribute an optional donation. All proceeds from these donations will go towards supporting victims of the COVID-19 crisis from across the world, through the excellent work of Médecins Sans Frontières.

The Fourth International VR Awards will be a first of its kind fully immersive awards show. For behind the scenes clips and sneak-peaks of the show, please follow our social media. And please make sure to donate when you grab your ticket.

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Yemen is the world’s worst humanitarian disaster. We couldn’t imagine that it could get any worse, and then the coronavirus pandemic hit. The figures coming out of Yemen are terrifying; 25% of people in Yemen with confirmed COVID-19 die, some cities are described as ‘infested’. This is like no other situation on Earth.

In the last 6 weeks I have lost a number of family members in Yemen to what sounds like COVID-19 - my aunt has stopped saying the names of people she knows who have passed away, and is instead giving numbers. My cousin was beside herself two weeks ago having just lost her uncle, and with her mother ill on oxygen. Her mother thankfully recovered, but then her aunt passed away.

We know these are difficult times, but if you can, please donate to a charity doing vital work in Yemen, Doctors Without Borders (MSF). There is a reason why they have the reputation they do, they have been attacked multiple times and yet are still providing life-saving treatment, on all sides of the conflict. In many places they are the only ones operating and providing coronavirus relief, whilst also providing medical care that ranges from lifesaving surgery for war wounds through to childbirth.

If you are unable to donate please contact your elected representatives demanding that they exert pressure on all sides of this conflict to a) urgently allow supplies, resources, humanitarian aid and personnel in and b) negotiate peace. Yemen is a man-made (not a natural) crisis, it is a travesty and the only real solution is peace. 

Here's the video for this campaign: https://youtu.be/b7v5ZA05KZk 

Why is it so bad?

Coronavirus is running rife in a population plagued by six years of war. Yemen’s population is suffering from disease and devastating hunger, and people’s immune systems are weak.

  • Half the country is on the brink of starvation
  • Diseases like cholera and diphtheria, which had been eradicated in Yemen before the war, are now rife
  • 1 child under 5 dies every 10 mins from preventable disease and 45% have permanent physical or mental damage from malnutrition
  • 50% of the healthcare system has been destroyed by this war
  • There is no properly functioning government to orchestrate a response
  • Because of the global economic crisis, donor countries are reducing or cancelling aid

The most advanced healthcare systems in the world are struggling to cope with COVID-19, please don’t forget Yemen. This stunningly beautiful and ancient place needs your attention. Our families and friends have been through enough.

What MSF could do with your donation?:

  • £6 / $8 can pay for seven oxygen masks
  • £10 / $13 can provide eight dressing for wounds
  • £17 / $21 can provide two leg splints to treat fractures
  • £31 / $39 can pay for 40 oxygen masks
  • £97 / $123 can pay for a physiotherapist for one day
  • £226 / $286 can provide a surgery set for an MSF hospital in Yemen
  • £828 / $1046 can pay for six folding wheelchairs
  • £1,806 / $2282 can provide eight surgery sets for our hospitals in Yemen
  • £3,679 / $4648 can pay for a physiotherapist for 38 days
  • £6,035 / $7626 can pay for five specialised abdominal surgery sets

For Americans looking to make a major gift and who are interested in US tax deductible donations, please get in touch with Rose Petherick on rose.petherick@london.msf.org

Looking to start up your own Just Giving fundraising campaign? Please do and feel free to use this video!

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
LASHaMAN is a global online lash competition run with one main aim - to raise money for the medics fighting the Coronavirus pandemic. All the entry fees in full are being donated to charity. A minimum donation of just £10.00 per entry per category is required to take part but we hope the competitors are able to increase this amount.

Naturally, we welcome donations from everyone not just those taking part in the competition.

MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. We are raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 40 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. In Europe, MSF is supporting health authorities in Italy, Spain, France, Belgium and Switzerland. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. eventName: Mikey and Sam's birthday marathon challenge
story:
We are running a marathon (26 miles / 42 km) before Mikey's birthday on 6th June to raise money for MSF. We have all been affected by the Corona virus crisis, but in other parts of the world they are not lucky enough to have access to our amazing NHS. 

MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. We are raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives.

How you can help:- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.Thank you.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Nick and I visited Yemen in 1997.  It was a tough holiday at the time - edible food hard to find, places to stay limited, transport tricky and our travel sometimes restricted due to the government's fear of tourists being captured for ransom by rebel groups etc.  For one leg of our tour the rules required us to hire a local armed guard.  But, looking back on this holiday, we felt incredibly lucky and enriched; we had seen an amazing country and we were made welcome everywhere with incredible hospitality and smiles.  

With Yemen so tragically in the news at the moment - although sometimes not enough, given the scale of their crisis - I hope that our photos may give you another view of Yemen.
title: Kitty's Yemen photos
pageSummary: I am sharing my photos of Yemen in 1997 because the people of Yemen need our support now.
pageSummaryWhat: I am sharing my photos of Yemen in 1997
pageSummaryWhy: the people of Yemen need our support now.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Sponsoring somebody to cycle 10km through a forest may seem a bit odd, so we (myself and a few fellow nutters) decided to make it more exciting by doing it indoors and measuring the distance vertically. We've "everested" before, but this

      https://my.rouvy.com/onlinerace/live/30890

takes it a bit further (to 374km horizontal and 10,023m vertical, to be precise). We're primarily doing it because it seems like a wonderfully crazy thing to try. However, we have no idea if we'll make it, so knowing that it's (also) for a good cause may give us the extra energy we're likely to need towards the end (i.e. for the last 20 hours, or so? Aaaargh.).

Why MSF? Because I've been fascinated by Yemen (purely book-based, I'm afraid) for a long time and what's going on there at the moment is a catastrophy. MSF are there to help. Help them! The target is £1 per metre of elevation. Probably a bit ambitious, but go and surprise us!

Finally: This is the 21st century, so we'll obviously live-stream this thing. Yes, on zoom. Feel free to stop by and leave a message in the chat. Kick off is on Saturday, August 22nd 2020, 6am (UK summer time) and I expect we'll be there for a while...


            https://zoom.us/j/99920036183

If all goes well, the "screen share" will show a live screenshot of the road ahead of me while you should be able to see me (and anybody else who joins the session) pedalling furiously (but less and less so as the day goes on...) at the bottom. Probably no sound since the fans (and music) are likely to drown things out anyway; and I'm unlikely to be in a chatty mood.
title: 10km through the forest. Vertical, that is. And raising cash for Yemen!
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: 10km through the forest. Vertical, that is. And raising cash for Yemen!

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Ordinary people are bearing the brunt of an increasingly brutal conflict in Yemen.

After five years of war, more than 80 percent of the population, 24 million people, need humanitarian assistance.

MSFs activities in Yemen are among their most extensive worldwide, but the needs remain huge while the healthcare system is even weaker than it was in 2015, when conflict erupted.

MSF is running the only COVID-19 treatment centre for the whole of southern Yemen. Their teams are working around the clock to provide the best level of care that they can.

How your support makes an impact

£10 could provide eight dressings for wounds 
£17 could provide two leg splints to treat fractures 
£31 could pay for 40 oxygen masks 
£97 could pay for a physiotherapist for one day 

Thank you so much.
title: Support MSF's medical teams to treat patients in Yemen.
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Support MSF's medical teams to treat patients in Yemen.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
eventName: In memory of Health Care Workers
story:
As you all know i have been leaving rainbow stones in memory of NHS workers who have died this year from Covid.  This continues.  But in December i want to celebrate NHS workers and health care professionals who continue to be our life savers, and will be hanging hearts with a workers name on, attached by rainbow ribbon.

If you like me to leave a heart for a friend, a loved one, a team who work for the NHS or work as a health care professional, i would be honoured to do so.   All i ask is for a donation to my chosen charity Medicin Sans Frontier MSF 

MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. I'm raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Some of you may know that I have been growing an absurd beard over the course of quarantine. My "friends" decided that it would look funny if I shaved my head as well, so here goes... The more you donate the more ridiculous I will look.

If I raise £100 I will do a #2 buzzcut (still shorter than it's been since I was born)

£200 will mean I  give myself a #1 (going to have to start suncreaming my head)

£300 and I will do a #0. (just straight up clippers to scalp. o_o)

If I manage to raise £500 then you are all amazing but also awful and I will give my noggin a full on wet shave and change my facebook name to Eggward.

Any money raised will go to MSF - who are an incredible organisation at the best of times, but in the middle of a worldwide pandemic they are crucial in protecting the most vulnerable people in the world. Please give generously.

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. Join us in raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis.

Yemeni hospitals are struggling to meet the existing needs of people and the spread of COVID-19 would place enormous strain on an already broken system exacerbating the already dire humanitarian situation in Yemen.

1,019,679 patients have been treated in MSF's medical rooms since the conflict started in 2015. 

After the first case of COVID-19 was confirmed in Yemen, MSF called for the authorities there to urgently allow the entrance of supplies and humanitarian staff into the country to prepare a response to the disease. 

2,200+MSF staff are currently in Yemen gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. 

MSF are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives.How you can help:- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.

Thank you for your support.

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
This December, while many of us spend time with friends and family, MSF teams will be away from home delivering vital medical care to people who've lost their loved ones, land, and any trace of security. 

The Rohingya people are one of the most persecuted minority groups in the world. Last August, a brutal campaign of violence against the Rohingya in Myanmar caused approximately 9,000 deaths. More than 706,000 Rohingya refugees fled from Myanmar into Bangladesh seeking safety. 

MSF have had to massively increase capacity to respond to the crisis. In one year we've treated approximately 650,000 patients. By making a donation you'll help MSF teams provide care to the most vulnerable.

£10 could provide antibiotics to treat seven patients.

£15 can pay for dressings kits to treat 12 people.

£20 can provide a cholera vaccination for six people.

story:
Our twins Rudy & Bailey have only recently attempted their first steps, so they are taking on the herculean task of stumbling 26 metres - their version of the 2.6 Challenge - in Highbury Fields on the morning of what would have been the original date of the 2020 London Marathon. 

Rudy & Bailey are toddling for Médecins Sans Frontières because it is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter Covid-19, including Syria and refugee camps around the world.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
owner: George Ripper, Michael Lambourne, James Lambourne
story:
Three seventeen year olds (George Ripper, James and Michael Lambourne) were training for the Dartmoor TenTors 55 mile endurance challenge on May 2nd - 3rd 2020. Normally a couple of thousand teenagers walk 35, 45 or 55 miles, climbing ten tors, over two days. 

The Covid-19 lock-down has cancelled the event. However this has not stopped us and we will each be completing a 55 mile walk (89km) around our gardens in full overnight walking kit. We are trying to make it as similar to the event as possible: starting at seven in the morning on Saturday 2nd May and finishing before five in the afternoon the next day.

We are raising money for MSF's coronavirus appeal to help support countries that are struggling most with the virus. (Please read below for more details). We really hope that you can support us, any donation no matter how small will be greatly appreciated.

We also want to do this to honour all the people who gave up their free time and weekends to train ten tors teams like ours - and for all the people who were due to take part and now can't.

Of course if you were also planning on doing Ten Tors this year, we encourage you to join in, doing the distance that you would have been walking next weekend. If you do, it would be great to hear from you; email georgeripper@gmail.com to get in touch about it.

MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. I'm raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. In Europe, MSF is supporting health authorities in Italy, Spain, France, Belgium and Switzerland. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives.

How you can help:- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.Thank you.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation.

We provide emergency assistance to people affected by armed conflict, epidemics and natural or man-made disasters, without discrimination and irrespective of race, religion, gender or political affiliation. 

We work in over 70 countries and go to the places where others cannot or choose not to go.

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Last week I watched this video whilst having my breakfast.  I think it is fundamentally wrong that in 2020 children are dying of malnutrition caused by starvation.  

Ordinary people are bearing the brunt of an increasingly brutal conflict in Yemen. After five years of war, more than 80 percent of the population, 24 million people, need humanitarian assistance.MSFs activities in Yemen are among their most extensive worldwide, but the needs remain huge while the healthcare system is even weaker than it was in 2015, when conflict erupted.  MSF is running the only COVID-19 treatment centre for the whole of southern Yemen. 

I have very little understanding of the geopolitical reasons for the war there or why kids are amongst the dead and dying due to a lack of food and medicine.  I do know there are people there trying to help like MSF and other charities.  I also know that in donating my time and money I can hopefully help them to help those suffering.  Even if it is only a little.  I hope you can help too.

Thanks, Paul
title: Support MSF's medical teams to treat patients in Yemen.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
This year, MSF UK is celebrating a special anniversary. Over the past 25 years, MSF UK has sent 4,329 experienced medical and logistical staff to respond to emergencies around the world. 

To celebrate this milestone we are dedicating our special occasion to MSF's life-saving work by asking our friends and family to donate to MSF, instead of buying a gift this year.

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Like most people in this country I'm massively grateful for the NHS, both for what they've done for me and what they're doing every day during these extraordinary times. But that's also made me think about what it's like for people without that safety net, maybe refugees crowded into camps or citizens of countries with already fragile health services. Which is why this appeal is not for the NHS but for a charity I've been supporting regularly for many years - MSF. 

MSF is currently providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives. Any support you can give will be welcome.

How this will work: If I get "sufficient" contributions (and Anne's desperate to do this, so the bar's set pretty low), I'll have my hair dyed blue as in the (photoshopped) profile picture above. If you're extra-generous (and I haven't already died of embarrassment), she has more colours. Thank you.
title: Support MSF as they respond to the coronavirus crisis.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
To mark Solarcentury's 22nd birthday, we have decided to set ourselves a 24h challenge in order to raise funds in response to the current Coronavirus crisis. 

On 26th May, which is our birthday, starting from 12am BST, at least one of our team will be exercising until 11:59pm, taking turns to cover the full 24h period. 

People from our offices around the world will join forces to raise money for MSF whose international medical work is more vital than ever during the Coronavirus pandemic we are currently facing. 

MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. We are raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives.

Where donations will go:

- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.

- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.

- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.

- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.

Thank you,

the Solarcentury team
