charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
In these challenging times, I have come to realise that I take many things for granted everyday. A warm bed to sleep in, proper nutrition and clean water to name a few. Doctors Without Borders (MSF) has launched an unprecedented effort to protect those who don't have access to these basic human needs. As they fight to turn the tide against COVID-19 in one of the greatest humanitarian crises of our time, I would be humbled by any contribution that you make to this fundraiser.

Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to combat the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF is deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives. How you can help:

- £7 / AED 31 can pay for protective plastic goggles for one medic.

- £16 / AED 72 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.

- £29 / AED 130 can pay for sterile gloves for 15 medics.

- £44 / AED 198 can pay for two protective suits to keep staff safe.

Thank you for your kind generosity.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Hi, my name is Ayana and I am a year 10 student in Oxford.

Since  the beginning of the Covid 19 pandemic, I knew I wanted to do something to help but I didn’t know what. Initially I thought of raising money for the NHS. Then I was reminded of MSF. In the UK we are lucky enough to HAVE a healthcare system. MSF works in less fortunate countries where millions of people struggle to access the most basic medical support. Currently they are providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the Coronavirus disease. In the UK, raising money for the NHS gets a lot of attention so I wanted to focus on needs overseas.

A year ago I cut my hair short -  it went from waist length to pixie cut. I wanted to get a buzz cut then but my parents were not keen. Now they can’t refuse because, with the UK lockdown, if it does look awful - let’s hope it doesn’t - no one will see!! 

So I found the perfect way to make a difference! Shave my hair for MSF. I hope you can help me make a difference by donating a few pounds to help less fortunate people during these hard times. I will keep you updated on how my fundraiser is doing and on my target date, I will share the video of me shaving my head!!

If I reach my target, at least 43 doctors will have protective plastic goggles or 155 medics will have sterile gloves or 13 protective suits can help keep staff safe.

Big thanks from me and everyone you will help.
title: Trading Hair for Help

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
The Music Players' Society is a non-auditioned society at the University of Sheffield, formed of 9 bands and ensembles spanning a wide range of musical genres. Each band holds a weekly rehearsal and we perform a range of concerts, gigs and events throughout the academic year.

We usually hold a free entry, whole-society concert in Interval at the Sheffield Students' Union in the summer to showcase the hard work we've been putting into rehearsals throughout the spring semester. This year, the summer showcase sadly can't go ahead for obvious reasons, but we were still keen to showcase what we'd been up to throughout the semester.

Following the success of our previous virtual performances of YMCA (Concert Band) and Gonna Fly Now (Big Band), we decided to put together a video showcasing pieces performed virtually by eight of our nine bands.

The MPS virtual summer showcase will be livestreamed on Facebook on Monday 15th June 2020 at 1pm GMT. Each band's performance will be available to watch after the event has been streamed.

We're asking for donations to the Doctors Without Borders coronavirus appeal to help support their medical teams in fighting against COVID-19 in over 70 countries worldwide. Please consider donating the cost of a drink in Interval to this cause. Even your smallest donations can help the charity to provide essential personal protective equipment to medical teams giving urgent medical care and support to vulnerable people. You can read more about Doctors Without Borders' coronavirus appeal here: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/covid19

Thank you for watching our showcase and for supporting this important cause. We hope you are all staying safe and well.

Big MPS love :)

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Ordinary people are bearing the brunt of an increasingly brutal conflict in Yemen.

After five years of war, more than 80 percent of the population, 24 million people, need humanitarian assistance.

MSFs activities in Yemen are among their most extensive worldwide, but the needs remain huge while the healthcare system is even weaker than it was in 2015, when conflict erupted.

MSF is running the only COVID-19 treatment centre for the whole of southern Yemen. Their teams are working around the clock to provide the best level of care that they can.

How your support makes an impact

£10 could provide eight dressings for wounds 
£17 could provide two leg splints to treat fractures 
£31 could pay for 40 oxygen masks 
£97 could pay for a physiotherapist for one day 

Thank you so much.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
eventName: Yemen Emergency Appeal - Doctors Without Boarders
story:
Story

Yemen is the world’s worst humanitarian disaster. We couldn’t imagine that it could get any worse, and then the coronavirus pandemic hit. The figures coming out of Yemen are terrifying; 25% of people in Yemen with confirmed COVID-19 die, some cities are described as ‘infested’. This is like no other situation on Earth.

In the last 6 weeks I have lost a number of family members in Yemen to what sounds like COVID-19 - my aunt has stopped saying the names of people she knows who have passed away, and is instead giving numbers. My cousin was beside herself two weeks ago having just lost her uncle, and with her mother ill on oxygen. Her mother thankfully recovered, but then her aunt passed away.

We know these are difficult times, but if you can, please donate to a charity doing vital work in Yemen, Doctors Without Borders (MSF). There is a reason why they have the reputation they do, they have been attacked multiple times and yet are still providing life-saving treatment, on all sides of the conflict. In many places they are the only ones operating and providing coronavirus relief, whilst also providing medical care that ranges from lifesaving surgery for war wounds through to childbirth.

If you are unable to donate please contact your elected representatives demanding that they exert pressure on all sides of this conflict to a) urgently allow supplies, resources, humanitarian aid and personnel in and b) negotiate peace. Yemen is a man-made (not a natural) crisis, it is a travesty and the only real solution is peace. 

Here's the video for this campaign: https://youtu.be/b7v5ZA05KZk 

Why is it so bad?

Coronavirus is running rife in a population plagued by six years of war. Yemen’s population is suffering from disease and devastating hunger, and people’s immune systems are weak.

  • Half the country is on the brink of starvation
  • Diseases like cholera and diphtheria, which had been eradicated in Yemen before the war, are now rife
  • 1 child under 5 dies every 10 mins from preventable disease and 45% have permanent physical or mental damage from malnutrition
  • 50% of the healthcare system has been destroyed by this war
  • There is no properly functioning government to orchestrate a response
  • Because of the global economic crisis, donor countries are reducing or cancelling aid

The most advanced healthcare systems in the world are struggling to cope with COVID-19, please don’t forget Yemen. This stunningly beautiful and ancient place needs your attention. Our families and friends have been through enough.

What MSF could do with your donation?:

  • £6 / $8 can pay for seven oxygen masks
  • £10 / $13 can provide eight dressing for wounds
  • £17 / $21 can provide two leg splints to treat fractures
  • £31 / $39 can pay for 40 oxygen masks
  • £97 / $123 can pay for a physiotherapist for one day
  • £226 / $286 can provide a surgery set for an MSF hospital in Yemen
  • £828 / $1046 can pay for six folding wheelchairs
  • £1,806 / $2282 can provide eight surgery sets for our hospitals in Yemen
  • £3,679 / $4648 can pay for a physiotherapist for 38 days
  • £6,035 / $7626 can pay for five specialised abdominal surgery sets

For Americans looking to make a major gift and who are interested in US tax deductible donations, please get in touch with Rose Petherick on rose.petherick@london.msf.org

Looking to start up your own Just Giving fundraising campaign? Please do and feel free to use this video!

story:
As you have seen, "Scrunchies Save Lives" is an Instagram account dedicated to making scrunchies out of leftover fabrics and giving them out in exchange for a donation to MSF's coronavirus fund.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
In memory of a wonderful wife, mother, grandmother and friend.  Thank you for all your generosity, and for all the wonderful stories of good times and friendship. We shall miss her.

I held a Jewel in my fingers
And went to sleep
The day was warm, and winds were prosy
I said "'Twill keep"

I woke—and chid my honest fingers
The Gem was gone
And now, an Amethyst remembrance
Is all I own

Emily Dickinson

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Hi Folks, I am currently on day 25 of the #75HARD challenge along with a friend of mine. We are attempting this challenge for various different personal reasons, one mainly being that we would like to raise money for MSF and Action against hunger charities respectively, during this especially difficult time. 

I have tweaked the trending programme personally and for 75 days I aim to;

*Exercise twice a day for 45 mins (one has to be outdoors come rain or shine). *Drink up to a gallon of water per day (this can include electrolytes). *Read 10+ minutes of a self help or entrepreneurs book/s per day. *Stick to a (predominantly plant based) diet - no unhealthy snacks or refined sugars, and no alcohol or smoking. *Take a progress photo every five days. If I fail any of the aforementioned I must start again from day one. This is no easy feat!

I have already urinated outdoors several times! On some days after a day of doing a HIIT class & a long bike ride I wake up aching all over (especially with my being hypermobile) and don't feel like exercising at all, so I do light things like hula hooping and swimming. Some days I have missed out on cake! I think myself so blessed to be able to do this. I am focusing more and more on nutrition and really want to hone the diet over the next few weeks. I cannot express enough how grateful I am.

Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives worldwide.

Upon completion of this challenge if I achieve to raise the target amount I will upload my start and finish photos (in my underwear)! I am aware times are tough for people during this pandemic and if you cannot spare a couple of quid that's no worries at all - if you can hit the share button that would mean so much to me. Let's raise some love and humanitarian aid for people across the world. Open hearts, open boarders... 

Many thanks, one love!

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Next week, I will be taking part in the ‘Cross Continents for Covid-19’ fundraising event. The event consists of a 48 hour relay that is taking place around the world, involving over 100 runners from across 6 continents. I will be running at 5:30am GMT on Tuesday (12th May) for one hour, before handing the virtual baton onto a runner, who will most likely be in a completely different continent!

The event is organised by my friend Lucy Metcalf, who I met whilst travelling across South America before Christmas. It was great to meet new people, and experience different cultures, as we moved from country-to-country. However, in doing so, there was a sobering sense of just how much people’s livelihoods and their families depends on tourism. The virus has inevitably meant that the tourists have stopped coming, as it spreads through communities, with little to no infrastructure to prevent the spread, and treat those who become infected.

The money raised from this event will be donated to Médecins Sans Frontierès (Doctors Without Borders) an international charity that, for almost 50 years, has provided medical aid to those who need it most. MSF are currently helping health authorities across the globe to provide care for patients with Covid-19, protect high risk and vulnerable people, and keep essential medical services running across a number of countries worldwide.

MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. I'm raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives.

If any of my family or friends would like to read more, or if you would like to donate anything towards my run, you can do so by clicking on "Donate" above.

Thank you / Diolch!


How you can help:- 

  • £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.
  • £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.
  • £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.
  • £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.

You can read more about their response to the pandemic here: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/news-stories/story/photo-story-responding-coronavirus-pandemic-around-world#p1

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
eventName: I Clap for Doctors Without Borders
story:
The Covid 19 virus has shown no respect of borders. Right now, Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease so truly a great organisation to support in these times representing a universal effort. 

Something else that is universal is clapping. In many countries around the world they clap to show their support for those battling the disease. We have been projecting this simple gesture in many countries.  

As humans we all clapped to show our gratitude. We clapped, clapped for our healthcare heroes, our friends, our family, for those battling it and those on the frontlines. But who do you clap for? 

This here all began with my son, Elliott, looking forward to clapping at 8pm every Thursday here in London. Each day he’d ask, “when is it Thursday?”, as he’d continuously prepare to go out. 

I would explain to him what the clapping was for and that we were clapping for those who kept us safe - including his Auntie who is on the corona team at Lund Hospital in Sweden and other friends, including many that were sick, his new heroes. 

Together, we made two clapping hands (he took the photo of mine to work from) completely out of denim (my usual medium) and transformed them into an animation - a clap. Home schooling! What was meant to be a personal piece of art to work on with Elliott, grew.

It was he who wanted to see it on the home projector. The next minute we were beaming it off the balcony... an idea was born.

We beamed it on some other buildings, and he thought it was like a bat signal, it didn't quite work on the roof, so I made a few calls as he wanted to see it on there. It led me to Andrew Hall in Newcastle, and when he found out what I wanted to do with a projector he said, I want to do that too! Though various networks it had now been beamed across the world, the pictures come in and you should see Elliott's face! 

I sent out to some of my contacts too and soon a piece of art showing a simple clap has been projected on fire stations, the sides of corner shops and castles across the world. 

It's been the length and breadth of the UK, then from Newcastle all the way to New Orleans. It's been seen in Mexico, Sweden, Italy, Colombia and we would love for it to reach you.

Please support us as we support Doctors Without Borders (MSF) as while we may all clap for many different people and organisations, we feel they encapsulate a spirit and do amazing work covering the whole planet, the only we will beat Corona, is if all the world is on side.  

Your donation will go directly to them, but will help drive us on and encourage us to make this platform to add to the clapping. It will support us to show those who we clap for.



MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. I'm raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives.How you can help:- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.Thank you.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
*Join the livestream on Facebook at 3pm today*

https://www.facebook.com/tis.oliver.david


Targets:

  1. I'll donate an inch of hair for every £20 raised up to a max of £320 ✅ [Target reached in 48hrs]
  2. I'll do a livestream of the cut at £500 ✅ [target reached 24hrs later]
  3. At £640 I'll do a personalised livestream shoutout for everyone who donated! ✅

After 10 years of long hair, on July 10th (it got postponed a day) I'll be chopping off my locks with a dual mission.

1. To raise funds for the brave work of MSF, saving the lives of folks in the most vulnerable countries who suffer the worst of COVID-19
2. To make an extra-long wig for a lucky lassy, via the Little Princess Trust (highlighting the additional struggles faced by cancer patients during a pandemic).

Why?
The fight against COVID-19 is only just beginning for the poorest nations in the world. Although lockdown has been tough for us in the UK, our neighbours face an altogether more dire challenge. How do you self-isolate if you're fleeing war, poverty or persecution? What if your nearest hospital is four days away?

  • Ten African countries don't even have a single ventilator
  • Hundreds of millions of people face financial catastrophe due to ill health or lack of work
  • Some governments are still in complete denial of the pandemic, providing little support for their citizens.

But you can help.

MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. I'm raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives.How you can help:- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.
Thank you!


*Up to a maximum of ~16 inches because I only have so much (and no, I'm not shaving my head...)

Further reading:
1. https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/apr/21/coronavirus-disaster-developing-nations-global-marshall-plan
2. https://scienceblog.cancerresearchuk.org/2020/04/21/how-coronavirus-is-impacting-cancer-services-in-the-uk/

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
eventName: Support Doctors Without Borders' work in Yemen
story:
Please watch the short  video link below. 

Yemen is the world’s worst humanitarian disaster. We couldn’t imagine that it could get any worse, and then the coronavirus pandemic hit. The figures coming out of Yemen are terrifying; 25% of people in Yemen with confirmed COVID-19 die, some cities are described as ‘infested’. This is like no other situation on Earth.

In the last 6 weeks a friend has lost a number of family members in Yemen to what sounds like COVID-19 - her aunt has stopped saying the names of people she knows who has passed away, and is instead giving numbers. A cousin was beside herself two weeks ago having just lost her uncle, and with her mother ill on oxygen. Her mother thankfully recovered, but then her aunt passed away.

We know these are difficult times, but if you can, please donate to a charity doing vital work in Yemen, Doctors Without Borders (MSF). There is a reason why they have the reputation they do, they have been attacked multiple times and yet are still providing life-saving treatment, on all sides of the conflict. In many places they are the only ones operating and providing coronavirus relief, whilst also providing medical care that ranges from lifesaving surgery for war wounds through to childbirth.

If you are unable to donate please contact your elected representatives demanding that they exert pressure on all sides of this conflict to a) urgently allow supplies, resources, humanitarian aid and personnel in and b) negotiate peace. Yemen is a man-made (not a natural) crisis, it is a travesty and the only real solution is peace. 

Here's the video for this campaign: https://youtu.be/b7v5ZA05KZk 

Why is it so bad?

Coronavirus is running rife in a population plagued by six years of war. Yemen’s population is suffering from disease and devastating hunger, and people’s immune systems are weak.

  • Half the country is on the brink of starvation
  • Diseases like cholera and diphtheria, which had been eradicated in Yemen before the war, are now rife
  • 1 child under 5 dies every 10 mins from preventable disease and 45% have permanent physical or mental damage from malnutrition
  • 50% of the healthcare system has been destroyed by this war
  • There is no properly functioning government to orchestrate a response
  • Because of the global economic crisis, donor countries are reducing or cancelling aid

The most advanced healthcare systems in the world are struggling to cope with COVID-19, please don’t forget Yemen. This stunningly beautiful and ancient place needs your attention. Our families and friends have been through enough.

What MSF could do with your donation?:

  • £6 / $8 can pay for seven oxygen masks
  • £10 / $13 can provide eight dressing for wounds
  • £17 / $21 can provide two leg splints to treat fractures
  • £31 / $39 can pay for 40 oxygen masks
  • £97 / $123 can pay for a physiotherapist for one day
  • £226 / $286 can provide a surgery set for an MSF hospital in Yemen
  • £828 / $1046 can pay for six folding wheelchairs
  • £1,806 / $2282 can provide eight surgery sets for our hospitals in Yemen
  • £3,679 / $4648 can pay for a physiotherapist for 38 days
  • £6,035 / $7626 can pay for five specialised abdominal surgery sets

For Americans looking to make a major gift and who are interested in US tax deductible donations, please get in touch with Rose Petherick on rose.petherick@london.msf.org

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Our lovely Mum died on 23rd August. She was 92 and had been living with lymphoma for nearly 3 years. Her original prognosis was 6 - 9 months but she didn't agree with that!

Mum was a nurse for all her life, mostly a district nurse. She was feisty, stoical, smart, kind, compassionate and the epitome of a matriarch. 

Mum was passionate about the NHS, but also really aware that many people around the world did not have the luxury of the care and treatment it provides. She was pragmatic about the end of life and didn't stand on ceremony, so rather than send flowers, we'd like to ask you to celebrate her life by supporting a cause that was dear to her heart. 

Thankyou

Maggi, Gill, Peter and Tricia x

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Short Version

We are all suffering with the outbreak of Covid19 however, people including medical staff in less fortunate countries than ours do not have the government support that we are so fortunate to have in this country. If you can, please donate today to help support the brave medical staff working in these countries - below is a list of how your money can help. 

- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.
- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.
- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.
- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.

Long Version

Whilst I understand the Covid-19 virus has had a profound impact on this country (and will continue to do so) the fantastic work done by our key workers and the charitable support for organisations such as NHS Charities Together has been astonishing, but we must cast our gaze further afield to countries that are not lucky enough to have a national health service like ours.  


With the UK sitting comfortably in level four (daily income in excess of $32 per day) many of us must consider the relatively privileged position we find ourselves in. So far we have seen an economic shutdown and over 20,000 deaths all of which are a tragedy. However, (and I know I speak for the majority here and not everyone) we have secure homes to live in, access to food, smartphones and other communication devices which allow us to stay both safely isolated at home whilst keeping in touch and informed and finally, many of us have access to some kind of income whether it be from the governments furlough scheme, social security or by other means. 

However, the same cannot be said for those living in countries in levels one and two who survive on less than $2 and $8 a day respectively and do not have the relative luxuries many of us are able to benefit from at this time. Their decision when it comes to social distancing and self-isolation is between staying at home to protect themselves from a virus they know very little about and dying of dehydration or starvation (a killer they know all too well) or; to continue to keep their families alive by carrying on with their day to day lives. Which involves walking long distances to fetch water from a communal cold water tap or a mud hole or congregating at “tap taps” (water trucks) in a cacophony of human jostling. They can stave off one killer but not both. Sadly, regardless of their choices and their attempt to protect themselves and their families, the outcome is likely to be the same and this is not good enough. 

Furthermore, compounding this problem is the insular manner of some of the international community regarding this situation, with historic world leaders hoarding and restricting the export of medical supplies all of which means countries on level one and two cannot gain access to many of the medical supplies they require. 

As one international healthcare professional recently told me “it’s tough, but if this is our health service being stretched we aren’t doing too bad” if you compare this to those in countries like Ecuador where relatives are having to physically search (dressed in bin bags their version of PPE) for their loved ones. They have to look through the corridors of hospitals checking decomposing corpses on stretchers, those still sitting in wheelchairs and those piled up in corridors before realising they cannot get a death certificate and they are going to have to bury them often in coffins made of cardboard.  

We are fortunate that in this country we automatically get access to ventilators, income assurances and more, but for others living in level 1 and 2 countries, this is a ticking time bomb. If you can, please donate today. If you can please share this site as unfortunately we all now know the power of exponential growth.

story:
Complete our virtual duathlon and help us raise some money for MSF! 

  •  5K run, 20K turbo, 2.5K run where you can complete the whole duathlon individually or in teams (male, female, open) of two or three and can be made up of athletes from any club 
  • All routes must be exact, run legs with significant elevation loss will not count. Elapsed time will be used rather than moving time.
  • All legs must be completed in line with all current Government guidelines and social distancing guidelines. We are advising that the bike leg is completed on a turbo rather than on the road. To accommodate this, we are allowing people to take part TWICE both individually and as part of a team. 
  •  Each leg must be uploaded to Strava and titled Virtual Duathlon (so that we can see elapsed and moving times)
  • All legs must be completes between Friday 1st May and Sunday 31st May 
  • Screenshots of all legs (both individual and team) must be emailed to eutrivirtualracehq@gmail.com by 12 pm Monday 1st June. 
  • Race entry £3 per person, all money donated to MSF via this JustGiving Page - please include your first name!
  • Follow us on Instagram @uoetriathlon and like us on Facebook 'Edinburgh University Triathlon Club' and remember to tag us and send us pictures of you taking part in this virtual race!

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Sadly our dad passed away suddenly in March 2020 while he was on holiday in Jamaica, aged 66. While the lockdown has made the grieving process very difficult and we were unable to bring him home for some time, I think its important to remember why we are doing this. I want to raise money to try and help some of the most vulnerable during these unprecedented times in memory of our dad.

As a doctor himself, dad dedicated his life to helping others and providing fair treatment to everyone. He also regularly donated to charities like this one. He really was one of the kindest people you could ever meet and I have no doubt that he would want to support this cause. He will be greatly missed by all of his family and friends.

I have started training for a half marathon during lockdown. I have my eye on the Norwich half marathon in October 2020, but am yet to hear whether this is still going ahead. From being quite sedentary, this is a tough challenge but I am making small steps towards managing the 13.1 miles! 

Thank you in advance to anyone who would like to support this cause xx

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
eventName: Katie Macleod Hall & Joseph Johnston's Wedding
story:
Ordinary people are bearing the brunt of an increasingly brutal conflict in Yemen.

After five years of war, more than 80 percent of the population, 24 million people, need humanitarian assistance.

MSFs activities in Yemen are among their most extensive worldwide, but the needs remain huge while the healthcare system is even weaker than it was in 2015, when conflict erupted.

MSF is running the only COVID-19 treatment centre for the whole of southern Yemen. Their teams are working around the clock to provide the best level of care that they can.

How your support makes an impact

£10 could provide eight dressings for wounds 
£17 could provide two leg splints to treat fractures 
£31 could pay for 40 oxygen masks 
£97 could pay for a physiotherapist for one day 

Thank you so much.
title: Support MSF's medical teams to treat patients in Yemen.

charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Hi everyone,

In March I will be running the Night Marathon of Luxembourg. This is my first one and hopefully not my last. This will be a big challenge and achievement for me !

I chose to fundraise for MSF as I had the opportunity to work as a journalist alongside NGO's in Iraq such as EliseCare or Be the Peace Be the Hope. In 2017 the war on terror was raging and the humanitarian crisis was at its worse. 

I saw first hand the consequences of years of armed conflict... ghost towns, soldiers going to the front, and packed refugee camps. To this day many health facilities have been destroyed and those still operating lack medical supplies and qualified health workers.

And now, to make things worse, the Corona virus pandemic is causing even more strains to health system across developing countries. This is why MSF work is so valuable. Operating and volunteering where ever they are needed. Dedicating their time to save lives often very far from home. 

It is my honour to raise money for MSF so they can continue to help those in need especially during this pandemic.

Please feel free to watch a short video I made during my stay in Iraq. https://vimeo.com/489039221

And until the day of the race I would like to thank MSF for fighting for such an important cause and everyone that will help me in this fundraiser to support them.

Merci beaucoup ! 

Victor 

About MSF :

MSF's emergency teams are experts at fighting disease outbreaks. I'm raising funds to support the medical teams on the ground as they respond to the coronavirus crisis. Right now, MSF is providing urgently needed medical care and support in more than 70 countries to counter the coronavirus disease. MSF's medical teams are also gearing up to confront potential outbreaks in the hundreds of areas they were already working before the pandemic struck. MSF are deploying medics, sending supplies and applying nearly 50 years of experience fighting epidemics to protect the most vulnerable and save lives.How you can help:- £16 can pay for a surgical tunic, trousers and a pair of sterile reusable gloves.- £28 can pay for protective plastic goggles for four doctors.- £58 can pay for sterile gloves for 30 medics.- £110 can pay for five protective suits to keep staff safe.Thank you.

story: I am challenging myself to drink nothing but water this January. I am taking on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. 

Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. 

It sounds normal and it should be.

story: Hopefully some good things can come out of this dreadful time in lockdown. I will be walking in and around Tunbridge Wells both with friends (one at a time of course) and alone to keep fit during these dark days. If any people who live locally want to join me on a walk, please contact me. My aim is to walk the full 50km of the Tunbridge Wells circular route on the Spring equinox (21st March). Up until then I will be walking bits of the route and doing various other local walks in and around the town. Everything is recorded on Strava along with some great pictures of our locale. Please donate if you can.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
When doing some research about water, Elijah discovered that the average distance children and women walk to collect water is 6km, and he was inspired to do something to help. For many, the daily routine to get water takes over their lives. Children often miss out on the chance to go to school.

Elijah, Cónán and Frankie (all 11 years old) are raising money for WaterAid, to help bring clean water and toilets to vulnerable communities around the world. On Sunday 31st January, they are going to walk an approximately 6km round-trip collect water in buckets and carry it to their homes, in different parts of Walthamstow.

The total amount raised will be matched by the UK government (until the 4th Feb) so your donation will go even further!

Since 1981, WaterAid has reached 26.4 million people with clean water and 26.3 million people with decent toilets.

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Diolch yn fawr, thank you.

story:
Thank you for joining WaterAid's Just Water bingo lunch. 

As well as being a fun activity  it’s also a chance to boost your fundraising, bringing the gift of clean water to others. We recommend you either donate to yourself or make a donation to this page - £5 per person is a good place to start! 

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. 

If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for your support with my London Marathon 2020 challenge! Your support will help WaterAid in its mission to transform the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people by improving access to safe water, decent toilets and hygiene.

I have chosen to run for Wateraid because I believe everybody deserves the right to have access to clean water. Not only does it improve hygiene and day to day living, it opens doors education and jobs, too. 

31% of schools don't have access to clean water. You can read about how Wateraid helps schools here: https://www.wateraid.org/uk/stories/inspirational-teachers-and-clean-water-the-key-to-childrens-futures

story:
I'm a bit late in the day as I already ran the marathon today, but as several people have asked me if they can make a charity donation towards it, I've set this page up. Massively grateful for any contributions, they will make a real difference to people around the world who need it the most.

title: Sair's London Marathon 2020 WaterAid page
pageSummary: Running the "virtual" London Marathon because WaterAid transforms millions of lives
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Sair's London Marathon 2020 WaterAid page

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I was lucky enough to get a ballot place in the London Marathon and am using this amazing opportunity to try and raise much needed funds for WaterAid.

I was obviously hoping to run the marathon in April 2020 but, thanks to COVID, things haven’t exactly gone to plan. As a result I will be now be doing TWO marathons, as I am participating in the virtual London Marathon on 4 October 2020 and will then be running the ‘real thing’ on 3 October 2021...eek!! 

Training for and running a marathon is one of the hardest things I've ever done, but knowing I am also raising money for such a fantastic charity will help make all the hundreds of miles of training worthwhile. 

785 million people around the world are living without clean water and 2 billion without a decent toilet. Your support will help WaterAid in it's mission to transform the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people by improving access to safe water, decent toilets and hygiene. Further information about the charity is available here - https://www.wateraid.org/uk

Thanks for taking time to visit my page/donate :)

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. 

Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. 

It sounds normal and it should be.

story:
As part of my Mayor of Henley award, I have decided to raise money for charity. I have decided to walk 100km in 4 weeks to raise money for WaterAid. I want to help people who can't get fresh water.

I will start on 16 January 2021 and I will finish on 14 February 2021.

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in climate-vulnerable communities.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Our Mum, Doreen, passed away on 11th January. She was a quiet, kind person who touched deeply the lives of those who knew her. To help celebrate her life and further her impact on the World we wanted to raise funds for a charity that was important to her.

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in climate-vulnerable communities.
title: In Memory of Doreen Turvey
pageSummary: We are raising funds because it was a charity that was dear to our amazing Mum.

story:
I know it may not be the toughest challenge. But I want to help raise some awareness and just do something a bit different to give a little at he start of 2021. I may not be a bug alcohol drinker, but I sure do love my coffee in the morning and hot chocolate at night so I think it will be harder than I realise. 

One of the most important aspects is that if you donate before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across the world. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I am going to walk 4 kilometres each day on top my daily routine for the month of March to raise money for the millions who have to walk miles each day in search of clean water. I would be raising money to support Water Aid and be part of the change with a hope that one day everyone would get clean water readily available . All you kind people have always supported me in raising money for good causes each time I have taken a challenge. I would really appreciate your support this time too. 

I will keep you informed as I go along.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
In March, I will be taking part in this event. Having travelled through Uganda and seeing the difficult terrain that villagers have to traipse to get water, the least I can do is help reduce the risks and distances that need to be taken. We take having fresh water on tap for granted, these people need to be able to feel the same way.


 I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Not only is Just Water the ultimate detox after an over-indulgent Christmas, but by fundraising for WaterAid i will be helping to change lives with the gift of clean water. That's right. No tea! No booze! No blackcurrant squash!! FOR A MONTH. 2 January to 2 February! 

ALSO...Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across the world. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk
title: Just Water 2021
pageSummary: Raising money for WaterAid drinking Only Water! because I want there to be taps and toilets everywhere

title: Melissa

Name: Melissa

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
When Walk for Water ad showed up on my Facebook news feed, it brought back lots of memories. I remembered the time when I had to walk everyday, sometimes twice a day to fetch water for everyday use and needs. It was not a welcomed chore. Nevertheless, in some countries people have no choice but to walk miles to fetch water for themselves and their families. Thankfully, I no longer have to walk to fetch water, but sadly, others still have too, and this is why I’ve decided to walk 4km every day for the month of March so that one day women and children won't have to walk several miles carrying a bucket of water on their heads. I’m walking to raise money so that people living in remote villages where water is scarce can have access to clean and safe running water in their villages..


Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
My Mum and I are walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

I know times are tough for people right now but if you can spare a little then it would mean a great deal to myself, my Mum and all of the woman and children who don’t have the luxury of water at hand. 

I would also like to say a massive thank you in advance to anyone who sponsors us. 

Take care Xx

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
In January I was challenged to walk 73 miles (as I'm 73 years old) by my Rotary club. Then I saw the 'walk 1,000 miles in 2021' challenge which I joined because now I have got walking I don't want to give up. Then I saw this Walk for Water Challenge in March, and I thought it wouldn't be too hard to increase my miles from 3 a day to 5 a day (just for March) in aid of this wonderful charity. I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

We are so lucky to take water for granted, so please support those who don't have it.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Water Aid has worded it so nicely below...

What I will do is to walk an extra 4km everyday, come rain or shine, irrespective of having to start work early and / or finishing late.

This is in addition to all of my normal daily activities.

Just to see how hard it is having to fetch water everyday, 

and to see how fortunate we are to have water on demand......



I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

charity.name: WaterAid
story: WaterAid is working to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. The international not-for-profit organisation works in 28 countries to change the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people. Since 1981, WaterAid has reached 26.4 million people with clean water and 26.3 million people with decent toilets.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I believe every child should have access to clean water.

I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.


Starting a challenge on the day you move house is a bit crazy, but at least I don't have to walk for water that day.  Join me in making a difference.

story:
Not only is Just Water the ultimate detox after an over-indulgent Christmas, but by fundraising for WaterAid you'll be helping to change lives with the gift of clean water. 

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across the world. 

If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
My son Joe and I have challenged ourselves to drink nothing but water this January. Giving up alcohol wasn't such an issue for me but living without my lovely herbal teas and milk for Joe has been hard. To be honest we thought it might be too tough so have waited 'til now to start fundraising. But with only 7 more days to go - we think we'll do it.  We hope you will consider making a donation for this awesome cause - everyone should have access to clean water. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia.

Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit www.wateraid.org/uk

story:

By helping me fundraise for WaterAid, you'll be helping to change lives with the gift of clean water. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across the world. title: Just Water 2021
pageSummary: I am drinking nothing but water in January because I want everyone to have clean water.
pageSummaryWhat: I am drinking nothing but water in January
pageSummaryWhy: I want everyone to have clean water.
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Just Water 2021
ProfileWhat: I am drinking nothing but water in January
ProfileWhy: I want everyone to have clean water.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in climate-vulnerable communities.

I was inspired to raise money for clean water after watching something on You Tube. It blew my mind that parents are giving their children water that could cause them significant illness and even death. Men and women are walking miles and miles to get water that’s not even safe to drink because they have no other option. I would love to raise a little bit of money to support water aid, in providing clean water to those who don’t have this basic necessity. If you have a few spare pounds I would be so grateful if you can give. I’m no runner, so I will aim to be able to run the full 5K by the end (or hopefully before!).

title: Stacey
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Stacey

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I am challenging myself to drink nothing but water this January to raise money for people who don't have a consistant supply of clean drinking water. 

That means no caffeine, alcohol or anything other than water between 1 - 31 January. I'm sure it will be good for me, but giving up my morning cuppas will be painful (apologies for my grumpiness in advance)!

It may seem a strange time to be denying myself one of life's remaining pleasures, but the restrictions this year have made me think about the things I take for granted. Who would ever have imagined we'd not be able to hug our family and friends this time last year? 2020 has made me appreciate the things I can rely on - our constant choice about what we eat and drink, the ever changing natural world, the ways we can connect with others from afar. 

I've spent time in parts of the world where water was collected from the local outdoor tap, which sometimes stopped working.  I always had the luxury of being able to buy bottled water. I can't imagine what it would be like to drink water, not knowing if it was going to make me ill. 1 in 10 people in the world don't have access to clean drinking water. 

For the people of Frat, a remote hilly region in Ethiopia, clean water is something that has always been out of reach. And our changing climate means the weather is increasingly unpredictable, putting people's livelihoods at risk. WaterAid's Future on Tap appeal aims to bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever.

I'm very pleased that whatever I can raise will be doubled by the UK government (before 4 February) through the UK Aid Match scheme run by the Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO).

If you would like further information about the difference your donation will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at https://www.wateraid.org/uk/future-on-tap-appeal

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

I have worked for and visited many of the countries where Water Aid is now making such a difference and seen the sort of hardship some people face. Since the earliest of those times the World population has more than doubled, demand for irrigation and other water supplies has increased phenomenally at the same time as climate change has reduced the availability disproportionally in those areas of delicate water balance between rainfall and evaporation  making access to clean water even more difficult. The need for help has never been greater.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I am challenging myself to drink nothing but water this January.

I spent a lot of lockdown staring out the window thinking about the people in the arid parts of Ethiopia, favellas of Brazil and the slums of Bangladesh and many other very poor areas and countries, and how coronavirus is affecting them. This is me doing my bit to try and provide soap and clean water to those people during this extremely unprecedented global challenge.

I am taking on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Just Water is the ultimate detox after an over-indulgent Christmas. Azariah and I will be giving up coffee, beer, wine, juice and other delights in an attempt to only drink water this January.

We are fundraising for WaterAid because we want to help change lives with the gift of clean water. Money goes towards the Future on Tap appeal to provide clean water to those who don’t have it.

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across the world.

title: Belinda ratcliffe
pageSummary: I have decided to do this again because Its such a great cause to raise money for
pageSummaryWhat: I have decided to do this again
pageSummaryWhy: Its such a great cause to raise money for
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Belinda ratcliffe
ProfileWhat: I have decided to do this again
ProfileWhy: Its such a great cause to raise money for

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
This is my third year of taking part in Just Water - am I glutton for punishment? 

Not only is Just Water the ultimate detox after an over-indulgent Christmas, but by fundraising for WaterAid I can help to change lives with the gift of clean water.

Today, there are almost 800 million people around the world who have no access to clean water. Dirty water muddies everything from health care to education. By raising money for WaterAid, we can change that and help bring clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone everywhere.

Last year was hard! As a tea-addict, I struggled during the first couple of weeks but it got easier and it di help me develop better habits for the rest of the year. I'm hoping this year will be easier, but time will tell!

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: I am challenging myself to drink nothing but water this January. I am taking on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
This is going to be a real challenge for me, anyone who has video meetings with me will testify that Ian very kindly keeps me constantly topped up with mugs of tea throughout the day. I also need to drink at least 2 mugs of tea in the morning just to feel half human. 

Not only is Just Water the ultimate detox after an over-indulgent Christmas, but by fundraising for WaterAid you'll be helping to change lives with the gift of clean water. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across the world. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

Name: Thomas

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
All donations will be doubled by the UK government until 4th of February 2021, so anything you can spare will make an impact! 

Shining the spotlight on our own flippancy when it comes to accessible clean water, I'm putting down the cokes, lattes, and pints this January by taking part in Water Aid's Just Water challenge. My teeth have never been happier...

Jokes aside, Water Aid is striving to bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world. With even the smallest donation, you can do your part in impacting peoples lives - and with UK-aid, all your donations are matched.

I will also be raffling off two £10 Vouchers to Wearth London, a zero-waste retailer. Anybody who donates is in for a chance of winning, just let me know you've donated to be entered in for the prize-draw on February 1st. www.wearthlondon.com

If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make to Water Aid and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit their website at www.wateraid.org/uk

Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

title: NatashaWing
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: NatashaWing

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Hi I'm Jordan, as many of you know there are a variety of challenges during different months of the year offering the opportunity to fundraise for a charity whilst improving your health and well being.

The most common challenge throughout the month of January is 'dry January' which involves the participants giving up alcohol. As I do not drink alcohol as often as I used to (Uni student life), I have decided to challenge myself to give up drinking everything and stick to purely drinking water. 

This will be a huge challenge for me as I love my cups of tea and coca cola.

All money raised throughout this will be donated to Water Aid.

Here in the UK are fortunate to have fresh clean water available to us whenever we want, unfortunately there are still countries that still do not have access to simple things as fresh water which most of us take for granted. With the help of this challenge I hope to raise money to help communities across the world have fresh clean drinking water. 

You can read more about their mission on their website 😀 

Please donate if you are able to, I know 2020 has been a challenging time for us all and  any contribution will be greatly appreciated. 

  Thank you for reading!

Jordan 👌

Not only is Just Water the ultimate detox after an over-indulgent Christmas, but by fundraising for WaterAid you'll be helping to change lives with the gift of clean water. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across the world. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

ProfileWhat: I am drinking just water for January 2021
ProfileWhy: I want everybody to have safe drinking water.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: I am challenging myself to drink nothing but water this January. I am taking on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

title: Kimberley

Name: Kimberley

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: I am challenging myself to drink nothing but water for the whole of January. I am taking on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid. Anyone who knows me will know that it'll be a tough challenge, being a bit of a (massive) sugar and caffeine addict! Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. Can you imagine not having fresh clean drinking water at the turn of a tap? It's something we all take for granted and don't even have to think about. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
So... we are challenging ourselves (yep roped Sean in too!!) to drink nothing but water this January in support of water aid! 

We have decided to take on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid and if you are kind enough to donate before 4 February 2021 your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia.

Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever.

 If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

Thank you so much for your support. 

Ashley & Sean

Xx

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I’m going to only drink water for a month to raise money for Frat, a remote hilly region in Ethiopia. The project aims to provide 50,000 people with clean water and any donations made before the 4th of February 2021 will be doubled by the government! 

Anyone who knows me or follows @the.buttercup.life on Instagram will know how obsessed I am with coffee (and wine!) so this might be challenging... 

If any kind friends think I need a cup of coffee or a night off you can donate £24 and buy me a 24 hour break hehe 😜

Lots of love,

Alice x

ProfileWhy: we should help people less fortunate in this world

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: I am challenging myself to drink nothing but water this January. I am taking on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Everyone who knows me knows how much I love ‘the occasional’ Diet Coke so this is a great personal challenge for me - I successfully completed it a couple of years ago and would like to try it again in 2021. Raising a few pounds for charity at the same time is a bit of an added bonus and makes going without the odd glass of wine or gin and lemonade more worthwhile and adds pressure on me to succeed. I will succeed - failure is not an option! 

I am challenging myself to drink nothing but water this January. I am taking on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

January is a hard time for everyone and I appreciate the financial burden that Christmas has on us all. Any donation small or large is very much appreciated and will go a long way to supporting WaterAid. If you can, give anything from the price of a can of my beloved Pepsi Maxx to the price of a bottle of delicious Edinburgh Gin, or maybe a lovely latte! If you’re not in a position to give financially, then why not join me on this ultimate detox challenge!
