story:
I am challenging myself to drink nothing but water this January. If I hit my target of £200 by the end of January, I will do it for the whole of Feb too!! 

I dont drink tea/coffee or alcohol anyway but I do have a major addiction to Pepsi Max!! Anyone who knows me well knows that I drink alot, so giving that up will be a challenge. Plus, just water for a month is boring! 

All fundraising results will go to WaterAid. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
The pandemic has hit everyone in different ways, but from day 1 the importance of good hygiene has been emphasised to everyone. But for those with no access to clean water or sanitation there’s limited ways to protect yourself and ensure the health and safety of you and your family. WaterAid always does fantastic work but in the last year the work they do to bring clean water to underdeveloped regions has been even more vital. 

To raise awareness and funds for WaterAid, Mat and I are taking on Just Water January i.e. Dry January v2.0 - no alcohol, no tea, no coffee. Just water. 

For Alex the no alcohol should be a breeze, but you really don’t want to see her without her morning coffee. And clearly for Mat (“lad of the year 2015”) you can guess where the difficulty lies. 

On top of that, we’ll be walking or running 6km every day as this is the average distance someone has to walk for clean water in the regions WaterAid help. It may not sound like a lot for us, but our current average on a busy work day is less than 3000 steps and it’s January (ie cold, dark and normally raining)....

And because that clearly wasn’t a big enough challenge, Mats decided to give up carbs and sugar for the next month (aka all the fun things). Count yourselves lucky that you don’t have to see him thanks to tier 4...

Ultimately, we knew January was going to be boring anyway so why not make it even worse?! 

If you have a couple of pounds you can spare for a fantastic cause that would be amazing and give us that little spur to keep turning down the coffee and G&Ts.

Also, until 4 February 2021 the UK government will match all donations to WaterAid, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across the world. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit www.wateraid.org/uk

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk
title: Rachel
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Rachel

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: Challenge yourself to drink nothing but water this January. Take on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid. Go 100% pure and give the gift of clean water. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: WaterAid is working to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. The international not-for-profit organisation works in 28 countries to change the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people. Since 1981, WaterAid has reached 26.4 million people with clean water and 26.3 million people with decent toilets.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
2020 has been an uncertain year for us all. One thing we have been able to rely on here in the UK is clean water.

Not in Ethiopia. You can make a difference.

With clean water, people will be healthier and able to grow fruit and vegetables in kitchen gardens, so they can have nutritious food whatever the weather.

Children will have more time to go to school, to have fun and to pursue their dreams, free from the burden of collecting dirty water every day.

The day clean water arrives will mark the beginning of their brightest chapter, giving everyone the chance to thrive and rewrite the rest of their story.

Future on Tap contributes to reaching Sustainable Development Goals 6 and 13 by providing climate-resilient water and sanitation to climate-vulnerable communities.

Each donation before 4 February 2021 will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in climate-vulnerable communities.

story:
Save the UK's Charities

General fundraising has been hit very hard by the COVID-19 pandemic. Thousands of fundraising events have been cancelled and many charities, particularly smaller ones, are struggling to maintain services because of this huge reduction in income.

This impacts all sectors of society  from children to the elderly  as well as the vital work in areas such as palliative care, serious diseases, mental health, housing support, food supplies and countless others that charities support.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
WaterAid is an international not-for-profit organisation determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. 

Sing for Water has been successful in raising over a million pounds in just over 15 years to meet this target. We need to keep on fundraising so that young girls do not miss out on education by travelling for hours to fetch unsafe water and make themselves vulnerable to attack in the process. Communities need safe toilets and washing facilities without exposing themselves to predation. 

There are singing communities around the UK who now raise money throughout the year for Sing for Water. If you can make it they would all love to sing to you outside City Hall in London by the water at the Thames Festival at 2 p.m. on 15th September 2019.  The collection buckets will be there!

My wife Rabia and I will be singing our hearts out (we think for the sixth time). We shall both have just celebrated our 77th birthdays and we want that also to become the norm for people in Malawi.

Water is indeed a matter of life and death. We have seen in some parts of the world how ordinary people have been forced to take on governments and the private water companies. Every penny counts.

Water Aid will spend your money on projects providing safe clean water for sustaining life and providing the means to health and hygiene.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Hi, I'm Julia and I am running the London Marathon in April 2020 for WaterAid. 

This charity is important to me as I believe that everyone, everywhere should have access to clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene. 

According to the World Health Organisation, an estimated 790 million people (11% of the world's population) lack access to improved drinking water and at least 2 billion people use a drinking water source contaminated with faeces. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone's daily life. Your contribution to WaterAid can help transform lives by bringing clean drinking water and life-saving sanitation to those communities who need it.

This will also be my first time running a marathon and I am thrilled that it will be the London Marathon. I know this will take months of grueling training and every little bit of your contribution will keep me going.

“Start by doing what’s necessary; then do what’s possible; and suddenly you are doing the impossible.” - St. Francis of Assisi

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I’ll be totally honest.....I 100% forgot I’d entered the ballot. I’m not even sure why I did. I think I probably saw the stats on the likelihood to get a place, (about 1 in 25 ballot entries got a place) and I figured there was no harm.....or chance.

When my ultra-marathon-running husband, John, (who literally runs marathons for fun!) got his “sorry, not this time” letter from Virgin, I offered a sympathetic shoulder pat and carried on with my day, blissfully forgetting my own entry. So when I received my “You’re in!” letter the following week, 2 words immediately popped into my head. The first was “oh”, and I’ll let you decide the second......(it was definitely “crikey” Mom & Dad if you’re reading this).

Knowing the extremely slim chance of getting in, I found it very difficult to think of a good enough and genuine reason to decline the place despite my total inexperience in long distance running. I’d just completed the Wolverhampton half marathon which was my greatest physical achievement thus far (after giving birth....obvs....) and if you’d told me I was only half way through the course after those 13.1 miles, I’d have thrown in the towel. It was SO tough and I know this will literally be the hardest thing I’ve ever done. But both physically and mentally I’m up for the challenge. 26.2 miles. Wowser....

So, if I’m doing this, I want to do some good. Pay it forward. I’ve chosen to fundraise for WaterAid because I believe clean, safe water should be available to every single person on this planet. How often do you taken water for granted? Leave the tap running too long, boil more than you need, not finish a glass of water and throw it away? I’m certainly guilty of all of the above but so many people don’t have the luxury of clean water and it costs lives and creates squalid living conditions. So anything I can do to help bring water to those without is a good thing.

Please please please support in any way you can. I am so grateful for any support, whether it’s a donation (obvs), offering to accompany me on a training run (you have no idea how grateful I am to those who have offered!) or standing on the sidelines offering me Jaffa cakes and fruit pastilles in London on 26th April.....I’ll be forever grateful. 

Let’s do this. Here’s to taps and toilets.....

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Hi everyone,

I hope you are all keeping well and that you have an enjoyable Christmas., and every blessing for the New Year. 

I can’t believe that it’s ten years since my 60 th birthday party ! and now just after New Year it’s my 70th !

I was going to have a party again like at my 60th. But now we will celebrate at home as a family .

I didn’t want any presents at my 60th but at this milestone I would love to do something different. Instead of celebrating with me and giving me presents I would like to ask you to donate to a worthy cause - WaterAid. Your donation will help towards providing clean water around the world and so save lives !

Thanks to everyone who is giving. You’ve help save babies’ and children’s lives around the world !

WaterAid say that a  third of the world’s population (2.3 billion) live without access to decent sanitation and 844 million are without access to clean water.

  • Some 289,000 children die each year from diarrhoeal diseases caused by dirty water and poor sanitation. That’s almost 800 children each day, or one child every two minutes.

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in climate-vulnerable communities.

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
A devastating explosion in the port of Beirut has killed more than 100 people, injured thousands, and destroyed countless homes. The disaster has also destroyed 85% of the food stock stored at the port  which will have a massive impact on the 1.1 million refugees who fled war in Syria currently living in Lebanon. 

Lebanon was already facing a triple crisis; with an economic and food crisis and the most recent COVID-19 health crisis. Beirut also has the third highest population of Syrian refugees in the country (hosting over 200,000 people) who are already some of the most vulnerable and stand to also be some of the worst affected by this latest tragedy.

Families are in urgent need of shelter, food, and emergency supplies. CARE is on the ground in Lebanon and our teams are rapidly assessing the needs and preparing to respond with lifesaving support to help families recover from this disaster.

Together we can help respond with lifesaving support for people affected by the disaster.
title: 50 Miles for Lebanon Challenge
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: 50 Miles for Lebanon Challenge

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
eventName: Shaving My Head for CARE International
story:
With over 70 years of experience, CARE International fights poverty and injustice in the world's most vulnerable places. I chose this charity as it works with women and girls at its centre, fighting causing including underage marriage, gender based violence, poverty, disaster response and healthcare for vulnerable women everywhere. 

I am personally choosing to shave my head and I hope this will show solidarity with women who have been robbed of so many things - whilst it's only my hair I'll be losing, it's a tribute to women who have had their childhoods taken, who have lost everything or were never given the opportunities they deserve. 

Please donate anything you can to help with this cause! I am aiming to do this on Tuesday the 11th August, but may well do it sooner if I'm able to reach my target sooner. Thanks so much for reading my page and considering. 

Melissa 💛

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Seventy five years ago, after WW2 ended, a kind family from America sent my family a series of 'CARE packages' containing food and other essentials, to help us through the post-war rationing period. I have never forgotten the feeling of knowing that someone cares, and the excitement of these packages arriving. In particular I remember the tinned sausages which were delicious, a real treat.  

I see a lot of people doing caring things for people in their communities during the current Coronavirus crisis, and it makes me happy to think that 75 years from now, these acts of kindness will be remembered as fondly as I remember our CARE packages. I hope this thought spurs people on to continue spreading kindness, because it really means a lot to those who receive it.

I am raising funds for CARE so they can continue their wonderful tradition of providing CARE packages today. In particular during the current crisis they are helping the people who need it most to prevent the spread of the Covid-19 virus around the world. Those living in refugee camps, or in conflict zones, or trying to cope in the wake of natural disasters, for whom an outbreak of disease could be especially catastrophic.

For those who live nearby in Godalming, please visit my garden and buy a pot of flowers, vegetables or anything that would be useful for your own garden. And for those far away, please consider making a donation instead. An act of kindness can last a lifetime.

Thank you for your support for my fundraising efforts!

Ruth

ABOUT CARE's Coronavirus Appeal

The spread of coronavirus has unthinkable consequences in the places CARE is already delivering lifesaving aid places where healthcare systems are already weak, and where disaster and conflict have wiped out long-term food supplies. Your donation to CARE's Coronavirus appeal today could help provide hygiene kits, clean water and emergency supplies to the most vulnerable families. Help me help others fight this virus the best they can. 

#CAREFightsCoronaviruswww.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/covid-19-emergency

charity.name: CARE International UK
eventName: LCFC Women Res & U18 Lockdown Run
story:
After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water.  

CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need.

Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances.

CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to womens and children's needs.

Thank you for reading. For more information please visit the dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis

story:
The situation in Yemen at the moment is an absolute disgrace to humanity. Horrific. Yet, insanely, it gets very little attention in the media despite it being one of the worst humanitarian crises in recent memory.

After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water. charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Thank you for supporting me to take part in Walk In Her Shoes! 

Every day thousands of women and girls, all over the world, have no choice but to walk many miles to fetch water for their families. Water that is often dirty.

Their daily routine deprives them of the chance to have an education, a job, and traps them in a cycle of poverty.

Your support can help build wells and water pumps closer to rural communities so that women and girls dont have to spend their days walking for water, and can plan for a better future.

For more information please visit www.careinternational.org.uk where their website is kept up-to-date regularly.

charity.name: CARE International UK
eventName: Cardiff University Acatude's Arrangement of Run the World (Girls) by Beyoncé
story:
With over 70 years of experience, CARE International fights poverty and injustice in the world's most vulnerable places. We have created an arrangement of the song Run the World (Girls) by Beyoncé in aid of this fundraiser. We hope you enjoy listening to our a capella arrangement and if possible, a donation would really help some of the poorest people to find ways out of poverty with the help of CARE. As an all-female a cappella group, we are passionate about educating women in poverty, and we felt this was particularly important to fundraise for.

The link to watch our YouTube video is: https://youtu.be/ZZyarTb5hJ8 

To join us on our a cappella journey, give us a follow @cu_acatude on Instagram and TikTok!

Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Please tick GiftAid when you donate; as this is for a non-profit organisation, every £1 donated will be matched by 25p from the UK government!

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
For anyone who knows us, this will by no means be easy. This
will be the first running event we have ever entered so you can imagine how fun running 26.2 miles will be. Most definitely jumping in the deep end with this and something we will remember for the rest of our lives.

Already we are going through some serious training (including both early morning and late evening runs) and dieting with Chris already able to run 5K in just 16 days of training from literally no cardio training since 2016. It’s why we think now more than ever was a fantastic opportunity to raise money for an amazing charity and cause so please donate as much as you can, however big or small.

CARE International works around the globe to save lives, defeat poverty and achieve social justice. They put women and girls in the centre because they know that they cannot overcome poverty until all people have equal rights and opportunities. CARE currently works in 79 poor and developing countries, helping millions of the world’s poorest people find routes out of poverty. They are there to provide life-saving assistance when disaster strikes, and to help people rebuild their lives afterwards and they are there to work alongside poor people and communities on long-term programmes to deliver lasting change.

Their programmes and  policy work tackle the underlying
causes of poverty so that people can become self-sufficient. They place special focus on empowering women and girls because, equipped with the proper resources, women have the power to lift whole families and communities out of poverty. CARE is non-religious and non-political, allowing them to deliver humanitarian and development assistance to anyone in need regardless of race, gender, ethnicity, age, religion, political view or sexual orientation.

Thanks for your support with my London Marathon JustGiving challenge!My page donations will be sent direct to the charity in a fast and secure way. Its efficient, saves time and cuts costs for the charity. Let's do this!

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
I will be cycling 896km across 26 sussex towns in 35 days. I will be cycling from a town beginning with A and finishing with a place beginning with Z. I am doing this to raise funds for The Yemen Crisis, the UN have described this crisis as 'the world's worst humanitarian crisis' with 21.2 million people require urgent humanitarian assistance, 9.9 million of whom are children. This is four fifths of the entire population.

I will be fundraising via CARE who are focused on helping the most vulnerable people in Yemen, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need.Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances.CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to womens and children's needs.

I am thankful for you reading this story and appreciative of any donations. 

For more information please visit the dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water. CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need for themselves and their families. In the West it is too easy to forget that so many people don't have access to basic nessessities such as food, shelter and water, and therefore we have a duty to ensure that we can help those less fortunate than us as much as we can.

Myself and three friends decided we would walk across the Offa's Dyke trail which spans from the south to the north coast of wales. We will be carrying all our food, tents and clothes on our backs. The walk is 177 miles, through mountains, valleys and rivers and will push us to our physical limits. Please help support us and help support those in Yemen by donating as little or as much as you wish. The Yemeni really need those lucky enough to be born into priviledged families to help them through this crisis. A little amount of money to you could be the difference between life and death for a child in Yemen.

story:
The Lunchbox Club was established during the Covid-19 pandemic to encourage those to make a 'isolation donation'. Many who have been fortunate enough to be working from home, and will continue to do so, may have found that they have saved money by not commuting to work. The Lunchbox Club encourages people to donate the cost of a lunch, train or bus fair, fuel or parking, on a regular basis to support vital causing during this uncertain time. 

For the next 4 weeks the Lunchbox Club will be raising funds for the Yemen crisis. 

After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water. 

CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need.Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances.CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to womens and children's needs.

We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
As a long time committed anti-runner I took a leap during lockdown and completed Couch to 5k. Since I reached that goal at the end of July I’ve done NOTHING! 

So a new challenge is needed to get those running shoes back on. 

It’s my 37th birthday on 21st September and from then until 21st October I’m going to run 25 miles, the equivalent of running the Inca Trail - but at North London altitude rather than mountains of Peru!

This is a BIG challenge for me but nothing compared to those faced by women living in poverty and conflict across the world. Any donations you can make will go towards CARE’s amazing, lifesaving work delivering aid in places like Yemen and Syria.

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
I have always been into exercise and sports, but now I am pushing this a little bit more: I want to prepare the London marathon (my first marathon) in only 30 days. 

I am already preparing for the bumpy ride! Read below to learn more about the challenge and CARE International, the charity I am fundraising for.

The challenge

  • A full marathon (26.2 miles)
  • Official participation (you can't escape now, Pietro...) in the London 2020 marathon
  • All of that prepared in less than 30 days

You can see my training plan here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1FoQVacB_R-Zo4pRwGEmJEzvJ1-SWuJWdp9-cFq0O1dY/edit#gid=0

Is it advisable? Generally not. Is it smart? You might argue the contrary.

So why am I still doing it? It's actually a very simple reason: I want to challenge myself both physically and mentally. 

The charity

    CARE International started by tackling poverty in Europe after the second World War. 

    My grandparents and parents experienced first hand the dramatic changes and improvements that Italy experienced from the 1950s. 

    If today I have a huge privilege is also because of the efforts and help of generations before mine for investing and taking actions in re-building Europe. Today, I believe our generation shares the same responsibility.

    CARE's mission is very simple yet all-encompassing: to reduce poverty - and all major factors causing it - in the world's most vulnerable places. 

    The vast majority of donations (~85%) are spent on international projects to improve the conditions of people living in poverty. 

    To name some of the most fundamental areas where money would be invested in: 

    • Fighting hunger with immediate relief
    • Improving health
    • Promoting women and girls human rights 

    You don't have to donate, you might already be donating to different charities or donating might not fit your current status or financial situation. 

    But regardless, please join me in getting more awareness on the situation and problems that affect very poor people around the world.

    I know we all go through hardships, but if you're reading this (which means you have internet access - a luxury that at least 20% of the world population can't afford) you should already consider yourself lucky :)

    Again, no hard requirements or asks. J    oin me in my journey of physical / mental challenges and learning more about poverty in the world.

    https://www.instagram.com/pietro.solaro

    https://twitter.com/pietrosolaro

    https://www.strava.com/athletes/18977017

story:
Thank you for supporting me to take part in the Lendwithcare Zambia Bike Ride 2020!Your donation will go to CARE International UK who are helping to cut out poverty at its roots.

This coming May i am cycling a 400km route through Zambia to Victoria Falls to raise money for CARE. As you know, i've always been on the chubby side ;) so this is by far the biggest challenge i have committed to in my life and you might ask why i signed up! Well considering i am from Zambia, being able to make a difference in my home country really appealed to me(along with some gentle encouragement from the Heathrow Airport Exec team) and i have always dreamed of doing a challenge of this magnitude at some point in my life.

The route will allow all the participants to see Lendwithcare in action and meet some fellow Zambian people who have benefited from a micro loan. So along with enjoying the experience, i get the opportunity to see the great work CARE is doing in Zambia.

If you would like to find out more about CARE international, its Lendwithcare program and my Ride, you can by visiting:

How it works: 


https://lendwithcare.org/info/how-it-works

About the Lendwithcare Zambia Bike ride:

https://www.careinternational.org.uk/get-involved/our-events/lendwithcare-zambia-bike-ride

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Our mum chairs the Board of CARE and we hear a lot about it. Whilst we are clapping and supporting our local NHS heroes and carers, we also know that the impact of coronavirus on people around the world, where healthcare systems are already weak, will be even worse. We can isolate at home with our family. We can buy food and we can still attend school from home. 

In countries where children and their families already are unable to do this the impact of the virus is unthinkable.

CARE is already delivering lifesaving aid in places where healthcare systems are already weak, and where disaster and conflict have wiped out long-term food supplies. Your donation to CARE's Coronavirus appeal today could help provide hygiene kits, clean water and emergency supplies to the most vulnerable families. 

We have decided to try to climb Everest. We have measured our stairs at home and this means climbing our stairs (over two levels) 1,580 times. We think this will also help us to get our exercise without leaving home!

Help me help others fight this virus the best they can. #CAREFightsCoronaviruswww.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/covid-19-emergency

story:
After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water.  

CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need.

Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances.

CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to womens and children's needs.

Thank you for reading. For more information please visit the dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
I'm going to be taking part in an Olympic Triathlon to raise money for the current humanitarian crisis in Yemen through the charity CARE.

Yemen's population is currently at 25.5 million people and 80% of  people are in need of humanitarian aid just to survive.

After five years of conflict, there's a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water. CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase the food they need. CARE is rehabilitating water sources, providing water tanks and is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to women's and children's needs.

Any donation would mean so much and would help massively!

Check out https://yemencrisis.carrd.co/  for more info and for some alternative ways to donate!

The dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis


Thank you!

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
#AWheelyLongWay

St. Catharine's College students and staff are walking, running, swimming, cycling, and rowing the combined distance of 3,500 miles (5,600km) over the 50 days from 11th November to New Year. 

Not only is it important to keep active and fit through lockdown and the Christmas vacation, but it's ever more important - with COVID ravaging especially the poorest people of the world - to remember those that don't have the food, shelter, education, or medical care that we at Catz are so fortunate to have. 

That's why we the people of St. Catharine's College are travelling #AWheelyLongWay to raise funds for the Yemen crisis through CARE International.  

If you're a Catz student, staff member, Fellow, alumna or alumnus - join us! Email "jcr.president at caths dot cam dot ac dot uk" for information about how you can help or get involved. 

If you're willing and able to donate - please give what you can!

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
I am raising funds to support relief efforts for victims of the Beirut explosion, in order to provide life-saving food, shelter and medical supplies. Any contribution would be timely and greatly valued by people that were severely impacted. 

I will personally match up to £10,000 worth of donations, and BP will match up to £4,000 worth of donations. So each £1 donated could provide up to £3 of relief. 

A devastating explosion in the port of Beirut has caused grief and destruction to a country that was already dealing with a multitude of crises. 

200 lives lost (and rising)

5,000 injured, including many that are still in critical conditions

300,000 people have had their homes destroyed

15bn USD estimated cost of economic damage 

This humanitarian disaster could not have come at a worse time for a country that has been dealing with an economic crisis that led the Government to default, and locals not having access to funds in their bank accounts. The currency has lost 80% of its value in the last year, and caused soaring inflation and unemployment. Not to forget a refugee crisis that has been overwhelming the country for the last decade as it is host to over 1 million Syrian refugees. 

The healthcare system, which was already stretched in dealing with the COVID-19 patients, is now in dire need of aid to treat patients of the explosion. Four hospitals were destroyed by the explosion, which is another huge setback to the system. 

Your donations would be go to CARE International, which is a UK registered charity working on the ground in Lebanon. They will use the proceeds to provide life-saving food, shelter and medical supplies for people that are most impacted.

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Why the London Marathon?

4 years ago I dragged myself around the Warwick Half Marathon as a "break" from revision and was pretty much carried over the finish line by the one and only running machine, Frankie Salzano (who had already finished and had to come back and find me.....) It was not a pretty sight and the St John's ambulance staff were not impressed by my 'drop to the floor' style finish. 

So, for comical value I'm back and I'm attempting the whole thing. Could go one of two ways but hopefully it will still result in a similarly dramatic finish for you all.

It would be fantastic to see as many of your faces along the way to help drag me along on the 28th April.

Why Care International?

I'm raising funds for Care International to help them with their aim to end poverty. The work Care International does to tackle poverty and social injustice not only saves lives in emergencies but also helps build longer-term solutions to give communities a better and more sustainable future.

I chose to support Care International because in their quest to end poverty and social injustice they focus their efforts on women and girls. Of the 1.2 billion people who are in poverty, the majority are women and girls who are denied basic human rights; health care, education, income and freedom of choice. Care International helps to build a sustainable future for communities in poverty, as they know that when girls get an education they build better lives for themselves and their families, and when women have an income, they invest in their children and create hope for future generations.

Any donation that you can give would be incredibly appreciated by myself but also the brilliant team at Care International. I will also be hosting a number of fundraising events so keep your eyes peeled for more details on these.

JustGiving

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
I'll be taking on the London Marathon in 2021 for CARE International UK, a charity that works around the globe to save lives, defeat poverty and achieve social justice.

The spread of coronavirus (COVID-19) has unthinkable consequences in the places CARE is already delivering lifesaving aid  places where healthcare systems are already weak, and where disaster and conflict have wiped out long-term food supplies. In these communities there are far too many vulnerable people and too few resources to fight a deadly virus like this.

CARE are building on past experience responding to outbreaks of infectious disease in vulnerable communities taking particular note that emergencies, including health crises, tend to disproportionately affect women and girls.

My page donations will be sent direct to the charity in a fast and secure way. It's efficient, saves time and cuts costs for the charity. Let's do this!

story:
The spread of COVID-19 has unthinkable consequences in the places CARE is already delivering lifesaving aid, places where healthcare systems are already weak, and where disaster and conflict have wiped out long-term food supplies.

A group of lawyers at Trowers & Hamlins has established a multi-jurisdictional task force and decided to buck our typical respective images and test our follice fecundicity to see what sort of nose neighbour we can sprout while we are working from home, all in the name of charity.  Our respective face furniture will continue to grow until office working is re-established across our network, and for one week thereafter.

Your donation to CARE's Coronavirus appeal today could help provide hygiene kits, clean water and emergency supplies to the most vulnerable families. Help us help others fight this virus the best they can.

#CAREFightsCoronavirus

www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/covid-19-emergency

﻿

charity.name: CARE International UK
eventName: Help Izzy Run for Yemen this September
story:
Hello everyone!

By now you are probably more than aware of the ongoing Yemen crisis and critical urgent appeals for emergency aid to fight the catastrophic famine and conflict faced by Yemeni people. 

Like me you are most likely reminded of this in the news and the late night urgent appeals on your TV screens. But also like me, you might  feel a little helpless. So this month I am asking you to work with me, through donations and a lot of sweating (on my part), to provide vital, financial aid that I am hoping will provide some relief, however small, to the wholly unimaginable and terrifying situation that Yemen faces. 

I will run 150 KM from the 1st- 30th September  For the moment this concerns running for 25 days of the month, averaging 36-38 per week, with 1 day per week for rest. 

Any donations, big or small would be AMAZING to help this incredible charity and will be sent directly to them via JustGiving. Your money will provide essential funds to facilitate the following: 

Rehabilitating water sources, providing hygiene kits and preventing the spread of waterborne diseases, namely, cholera. Essential water supplies also reduces the risk of vulnerable women and children making dangerous, long journey's to water sources where they are at risk of sexual violence. 

Distribute essential food, cash and vouchers to provide much needed supplies to families, as well as agricultural training to local communities. 

Support highly vulnerable women, empower young children through education and vocational training to provide them with opportunities. 

Please do check out CARE (Yemen Crisis) online to see further details!

Thank you for your help :) 

Addition Information by Care:

After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water. CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need.Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances.CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to womens and children's needs.Thank you for reading. For more information please visit the dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
This is a community fundraising page, for the residents and community groups of Bournville to come together to raise awareness and funds for the humanitarian crisis being inflicted on families and children of Yemen as a result of war.

Currently our planet is experiencing a problem of epic proportions, with the development of the viral pandemic crisis. The impact of this has been exacerbated in the Yemen by a conflict for control of the country between warring factions. Yemen's health system has virtually collapsed leaving the country incapable of coping with a pandemic having endured five years of war. 

As is often the case, the children of the Yemen, are the greatest casualties of the battle for control. During the war, children are the innocent victims, often denied access to adequate food or to medical care. Many of them are withering away in the Yemen's arid climate. Currently two million children are acutely malnourished. 

We have to do something to improve the conditions of the people, particularly the children. Let's come together as a community to support people living through the world's worst humanitarian crisis. 

The money that you generously donate will enable CARE to: distribute food and supplies to families in need, rehabilitate water sources, and provide women with hygiene kits and livelihoods training, all to provide life-saving assistance to the people of Yemen. 

If you are unable to donate or would like to help further, please share this justgiving page with as many community and school groups, and friends, as possible to help raise awareness and funds for Yemen in crisis. 

For more information please visit the dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
We are a family of six (definitely not the fittest) from Swansea, Wales. We like many of you are never short of food, comforts, security and safety. It completely breaks our hearts that people especially children in this day and age do not have access to these basic necessities. 

After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water. The charity we have decided to donate to: CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need.Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances.CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to women's and children's needs.

We plan to walk/run/cycle 50km a day for two weeks raising money to support CARE International's relief efforts in Yemen. Please support us generously, we are physically challenging ourselves against all weather, age and ailments!

story:
Hamza, Hari, Ed, Adersh, Will and Roshan are cycling 300 miles between Bath and Norwich to raise funds for CARE International UK's Yemen Crisis appeal.

After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water. CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need.Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances.CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to womens and children's needs.Thank you for reading. For more information please visit the dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis

story:
On Sunday 6th September I will be putting on my trainers out here in New Zealand to embark on a half-marathon in aid of the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Yemen. I have never been a long-distance runner of any kind, but a half-marathon is something I've long talked about doing, so no longer will excuses be made! 

The first weekend of September I will be driving up from Wellington to Taupo (about a five hour drive) to take part in what looks like a great challenge around the scenic Lake Taupo. Any donations, however small, are gratefully received, Obviously there is so much going on in the world right now so I really do appreciate your support. 

Here's a bit more info about this important cause:

After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water. CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need.

Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances.CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to womens and children's needs.Thank you for reading. For more information please visit the dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Support us!

We are taking part in an epic trek to raise awareness and aid for those affected by the Beirut Explosion.

Please support our team along this epic journey with whatever donation you can. Together we can complete our journey and help those in need along the way by raising funds and awareness. Every penny donated to this cause makes a huge amount of difference.

Please help us get this message out by sharing this journey of hope, we welcome anyone who can contribute or help us raise awareness and provide support for those effected by the explosion in Beirut.

Some words from CARE international on the crisis in Beirut:

CARE International UK:

‘A devastating explosion in the port of Beirut has killed
more than 100 people, injured thousands, and destroyed countless homes. The
disaster has also destroyed 85% of the food stock stored at the port which will
have a massive impact on the 1.1 million refugees who fled war in Syria
currently living in Lebanon.

Lebanon was already facing a triple crisis; with an
economic and food crisis and the most recent COVID-19 health crisis. Beirut also has the third highest population of Syrian refugees in the country (hosting over 200,000 people) who are already some of the most vulnerable and stand to also be some of the worst affected by this latest tragedy.

Families are in urgent need of shelter, food, and emergency supplies. CARE is on the ground in Lebanon and our teams are rapidly
assessing the needs and preparing to respond with lifesaving support to help families recover from this disaster’

#runforrelief

story:
A devastating explosion in the port of Beirut has killed more than 100 people, injured thousands, and destroyed countless homes. The disaster has also destroyed 85% of the food stock stored at the port  which will have a massive impact on the 1.1 million refugees who fled war in Syria currently living in Lebanon. 

Lebanon was already facing a triple crisis; with an economic and food crisis and the most recent COVID-19 health crisis. Beirut also has the third highest population of Syrian refugees in the country (hosting over 200,000 people) who are already some of the most vulnerable and stand to also be some of the worst affected by this latest tragedy.

Families are in urgent need of shelter, food, and emergency supplies. CARE is on the ground in Lebanon and our teams are rapidly assessing the needs and preparing to respond with lifesaving support to help families recover from this disaster.

Together we can help respond with lifesaving support for people affected by the disaster.

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Thank you for supporting me to take part in Walk In Her Shoes 2020! Your donation will go to CARE International UK who are helping to cut out poverty and deprivation at its roots.

Yes I believe in going to the root of a matter and cutting it down. I have been walking in her shoes since 2018. 

The month of June is my birthday.  I shall be walking 70km in total in the month of June to raise money. I want to make a difference, at a time that makes a difference.

When there is war, famine and deprivation, women who already in most societies suffer inequalities, also experience a greater impact from  these devastations. 

By empowering a woman to feed her family, educate her kids, overcome the effects of war and climate change, you are ensuring our world is a better place to live in. 

My plan is to walk between 5k -10km a day  until I complete my 70km target. Starting on my birthday 7th June. 

Please, please join me in making a difference and empowering women in deprived and ravaged parts of our world.

I will endeavour to provide updates of my walks, the insights I am getting and areas of focus.

You are making a difference, getting to the root of the issues that impact our world.

Thank you, Thank you very much for your support.

Much Love 

To Your Success, Health and Happiness

Patience x

eventName: Lisa's Yemen Fundraiser / Prosiect Yemen Lisa
story:
I'm raising money for the CARE International UK Yemen Crisis because I've seen the impact of the war, famine and Covid-19 on social media, and it has made me feel like I want to help in some way. Yemen has been described by the United Nations as 'the world's worst humanitarian crisis.' People die every minute, due to different causes. Every 10 minutes, a child dies from malnutrition or disease. They need help and I want to try to change the lives of some children, to give them a future.
I hope to raise a significant amount of money. I'm starting with an ambition of raising £150.
I want to raise people's awareness of Yemen's condition, and how people are suffering there, to encourage them to support my project.
I'll come up with creative ideas to raise money for the charity.
I hope my project will inspire others to raise money to support the people of Yemen as well.
I expect this project to take up a great deal of my time over the coming months.
Initial fundraising ideas are: dog walking, weeding, designing things to sell and being sponsored to do things. I hope many people will want to support this good cause.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Rydw i yn codi arian i CARE International UK Yemen Crisis oherwydd rydw i wedi gweld effaith y rhyfel, newyn a Covid-19 ar gyfryngau cymdeithasol, ac mae wedi gwneud imi deimlo fel fy mod eisiau helpu mewn rhyw ffordd. Mae Yemen wedi cael ei ddisgrifio gan y Cenhedloedd Unedig fel ‘argyfwng dyngarol gwaethaf y byd.’ Mae pobl yn marw bob munud, oherwydd achosion gwahanol. Bob 10 munud, mae plentyn yn marw o ddiffyg maeth neu o afiechyd. Maen nhw angen help a hoffwn drio newid bywydau rhai plant, i roi dyfodol iddyn nhw.
Gobeithiaf godi swm sylweddol o arian. Dwi’n cychwyn gydag uchelgais o godi £150.
Dwi eisiau codi ymwybyddiaeth pobl o’r cyflwr mae Yemen mewn, a’r ffordd mae pobl yn dioddef yno, er mwyn eich annog i gefnogi fy mhrosiect.
Byddaf yn dod i fyny gyda syniadau creadigol i godi arian i’r elusen.
Dwi’n gobeithio gwneith fy mhrosiect ysbrydoli pobl eraill i godi arian i gefnogi pobl Yemen hefyd.
Dwi’n disgwyl i’r prosiect yma gymryd dipyn o fy amser dros y misoedd nesaf. Syniadau cychwynnol i godi arian yw: cerdded cŵn pobl, chwynnu, cynllunio pethau i werthu a chael fy noddi i wneud pethau.
Dwi’n gobeithio bydd llawer o bobl eisiau cefnogi’r achos da yma.

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Wishing Stewart all the best, here’s to a well-deserved and happy retirement! 

A note from Stewart:

After almost 25 years it is time to move on, I don’t want a traditional leaving collection but if you want to make a donation I have chosen CARE who we have supported before and have been supporting the people of Lebanon since 2006 . They need our support more than ever following the devastating explosion at the Port.


________________________________________________________________________

A devastating explosion in the port of Beirut has killed more than 100 people, injured thousands, and destroyed countless homes. The disaster has also destroyed 85% of the food stock stored at the port which will have a massive impact on the 1.1 million refugees who fled war in Syria currently living in Lebanon. Lebanon was already facing a triple crisis; with an economic and food crisis and the most recent COVID-19 health crisis. Beirut also has the third highest population of Syrian refugees in the country (hosting over 200,000 people) who are already some of the most vulnerable and stand to also be some of the worst affected by this latest tragedy.Families are in urgent need of shelter, food, and emergency supplies. CARE is on the ground in Lebanon and our teams are rapidly assessing the needs and preparing to respond with lifesaving support to help families recover from this disaster.Together we can help respond with lifesaving support for people affected by the disaster.

Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water. 

It caught my attention on BBC news, when it was finally covered how devastating some peoples lives are in Yemen. Yemen is suffering from one of the world's worst humanitarian crisis. It hurts to think we have stores and stores full of food in the UK and so much wastage, where a mere fraction would be so useful to supporting the other side of the world. It is so sad to think that 85,000 children under 5 have died from starvation!

We know how devastating Covid-19 has been on our day to day lives and just think, how Yemen would have felt, when they already had the pressure of war and famine to deal with. 

I have made this page in hope of raising funds to contribute towards Yemen's famine crisis. If any of you have little nephews, nieces, sons and daughters, please empathise with the many mothers who are scared of losing their children. Please donate what you can - whether it be £3, £5 or £10 and so on towards a cause you know are serving the helpless. I would appreciate it! 

I will be donating £40 to CARE and in addition will be meeting targets of my own. I have recently got back into running after a chronic injury and want to get better timings running around my local park and will be reporting these times. I also have always been interested and protective of society's minorities that are disadvantaged - whether that be mental health, physical disability and people with impairments. The minority I want to focus on are deaf people and how sign language is not commonly known nor taught. Due to this lack of accommodation and preventable communication barrier, many deaf people must feel side-lined by society. Therefore,  I will be learning 20 sign language phrases (British Sign Language), in addition to the alphabet, and will be posting these learnings on social media (FB and instagram). My aim is to focus on these targets, of improved running times and BSL learning, for 30 days. 

Here's a little more about CARE...

 CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need. Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances. CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to womens and children's needs.Thank you for reading. For more information please visit the dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis
